lg.l: Blind Seer with the soul's all-piercing eyes!
Son of Urania! Bard of Paradise!
Milton! the triumph of whose epic fame
Shall roll in ever-gathering pomp, and rise
With distance louder on the world's acclaim!
When those usurping names now fondly dinn'd
Abroad by Fashion's folly babbling brood,
Shall have been swept by Truth's prevailing wind,
Like weeds, to where upon Time's wasteful shore
Oblivion watcheth for his mortal food --
Shall have been syllabled by Repute no more
For ages. Yea; and then his golden lore
By kindred spirtis meetlierwiselier understood,

l.add: And meetlier than before,

lg.l: The humbled Epic Muse to glory shall restore.
Monarch of Song supreme! defeat and blame
In the comparison shall surely dwell,
For him who with a rival's boast shall claim
To search the blissful fields of Heaven as well,
And by the ghastly light of penal flame
Venture so far into the wastes of Hell.*
For look upon his genius in its free
And fearless voyage through Infinity,
Must the prim rhymers of more modern time,
As emulous sparrows perched on brambles eye
The noble eagle on his path sublime,
Through the dim vistas of a clouded sky,
--Lone sailing, -- like that ship wherein did fare
--Glorious Columbus, when first seen to trace
--The bays of a new world, -- lone sailing where
--Log cape-like vapors bank the [gleaming spekcless] depths of Space.
'Taught by the heavenly Muse to venture down
The dark descent,' he saw the World of Dole,
With all its rueful gulfs in heaps upthrown,
Where the dread surges in their broken roll

note.p:
The opening portion of this section, if not the whole
of it, was, I recollectremember, written in contemptuous allusion
to Dryden's irreverent and tasteless idea of re-writing
in rhyme! the Paradise Lost.

lg.l: Wedged up like crags of fire, in prospect shown
Through blasting storms that deafened o'er the howl
Of universal bale, and thence did wage
Blind siege along Hell's stedfast cope, or bowl
In horrible conlfict round, with undiminishable rage!
See tower-like Demons crowding through the gloom,
Clashing, indignant of their terrible doom,
Their gleamy shields! that as they serry far
Out into the dark, its lurid depths Mume
With mixing curves and intermittant rings,
As lurking lightnings all the black clouds scar
With sudden shapes of dragon-semblant things,
When first the thunders of a tempest boom!
Or where that earliest birth of Ruin's womb
The Pandemonium of their grisly kings,
Upblazing, a malignant splendor flings,
They mass in legions duskily descried
Through that weird light's inconstant flickerings!
Others aloft in furious whirlwinds ride
Practising battle; or in banded hordes
Under the conduct of their several lords,
On bold discovery wander far and wide,
And with a pale astonishment admire
Those dens of desolation where abide
Chimera monstrous births, or list those dire
And ghastly uproars ever heard beside
The infernal rivers, whose drear tides reach wild
Out through the Alps of Death, dim in the distance piled.
Next us from forth the Ark afar and fast
The dove o'er the unbounded deluge swept,
Seeking for Land, -- so, o'er the limitless Vast
That erst enwombed Creation, outward leapt
His daring Muse; borne on the lightning wings
Of prophecy, and which as on they past
And threw broad splendors o'er all covert things,
Revealed its Anarch legioned wide around
With haggard Phantoms, such as madness flingsbrings
Athward some mind that with distempered strength
Outgrows the actual world. That Gulf profound
Thus did she voyage, -- to return at length
With tidings of the secrets drear and dread
That in its loud and horrible riots dwell --
Of shoreless seas; of igneous skies that shed
A hail of fire with many a writhing swell
And inward knashing as aloft they hung;
Of bedless bogs; of deserts drifting dead;
Of homeless mountains that still onward fled
Like clouds, or, meeting in huge justle, rung
With grinding thunders till perchance they sped
Within some Void, -- when, caught as by a spell,
Together there a sullen space they swung
In silence -- hushed at once; then lumbering fell
Downward for ever! These she saw outflung
In one confusion 'twixt the bounds of Hell,
And where, back shrinking as in grim surprise,
THe skirts of Chaos reflect Creation's coasting skies.*
Through brightening spaces now Urania soars,
Leaving the regions of phantasmal glooms:
Hark! from above a wondrous music pours,

note.p:
Here, carried away by his imagination, the Author has
established a Chaos differing rather widely from Milton's
-- and differing no doubt for the worse, as being less philoso-
phical. Of this, however, he was quite aware when writing
the passage, though somewhat young at the time, and too
ardent to be very critical. But he had thrown the ruins upon
the neck of his Pegasus for the occasion, so as to let him fly wilfullywide,
wildand somewhat wildly, though not altogether at random.

lg.l: And thrilling o'er, in widening circuitcircling over, wave on wave, out, roams
Far into Chaos; for the living doors
Of Heaven, before her, are self-opening, hued
With lamping glories of celestial gold,
And turned on hinges inwardly endued
With a melodious spirit. They unfold,
And out on the wild front of Darkness old
Flames a vast splendorradiance! while beyond in view
The measureless expanses are unrolled
Of an immortalising World of light
And sempeternal beauty! peopled through
With Powers and with Virtues burning bright
In the reflected strength of God, and who
Legioned together in supernal state
And blissful willinghood, day without night
The sacred Throne encircling, celebrate
In anthems thundrous withthrough august delight,
Him, the eternal, omnipotent One
Who knowing all things yet is known of none:
All stable good that beeth or can be --
Sole God of gods -- the indivisibleall-includingworldwhole all Deity!

l.add: VI.

lg.l: And now from Heaven descended, to the Bower
In Paradise we are led, -- where Raphael lends
At Adam's board his presence till the hour
Of evening warn him thence. Like that of friends
Their converse: now we list the Angel tell
Of that wild warfare which in Heaven befell,
When his proud standard Satan there unfurled,
Defying God! and listening, apprehend
A rushing turmoil such as might attend
The starry frame of all this nether world
In ruin -- system against system hurled!
Then tells he how at God's command arose,
Burning in beauty through the darkness, out
Of Chaos and Old Night, whatever glows
In all this vast of worlds; and how the shout
Of Angel myriads in wonder burst
And filled all nature with triumphant throes,
When they beheld the new born glories first!
And when the heavenly Historian's voice
Suspends awhile, -- look we around, and lo
All animals, immortal all, rejoice
In pristine innocence: the wolf and the roe,
The lion and the lamb, the hound and hare,
The horse with proud mane peacefully a-flow,
The sleek cat purring in the marmot's lair,
The pard, ox, elephant, -- one happy crowd!
With serpents, beautiful as threads of cloud
When they hang burning o'er the horizon's hoop,
At sunset, -- all in concord feed or play
Under some broad-spread tree whose branches droop
Loaded with globes of edible gold alway.
And flowers and blossoms of divinest hues,
And breathing all as sweetly as if they
Were blissfully conscious, in star-clusters spring
Beneath or bloom above; and warblers whose
Bright plumes are painted by Perfection, sing
Amid them, or, like winged Ioys, effuse
Their songs in flight, and, overflying, fling
Swift spendlors, that like rainbows span the clear
Lit spaces 'twixt the intershadowingsbillowy shadows leafiness shed
OfOfFrom neighbouring groves; while insect myriads near,
Buzzing, or volant on expanded wingsborn on fan-like pennons spreadfan-borne (volant none the less),
And glowing in such glory as to appear
Incarnate ardors, -- all in concert ring
Murmurous peals of dizzy-mixing sound
Such as intone the shining hours of Spring,
Blithely monotonous; and lapsing round
With many an intermissive gleamy glance,
Rivers of health amid the fruitful trees
Keep cadence with them, as their branches dance
To the invisible gladness of a breeze
There weaving into one all Eden's harmonies.
Now turn we to the Bower again, to hear
Adam his happy history relate; --
Into the affable Archangel's ear
PouringHe pours the blest experience of a state
Only inferior to his own, and dear
Even as a brother's welfare to a brother:
While busied near them, his so precious mate
And dainty ultimate of all delight,
The Garden's gentle Empress -- Eve our mother,
Clothed only with her grace, in such sweet plight
Is moving, and with manners so profuse
Of lovely influence and magic might,
As doth by royal right divine induce
Palpable homage from whatever wings
The air, and walks the ground, -- and even beguile
Tokens of heed from now-insensate things!
Yea, quickened with a fresher spirit while
She looketh on them, are the flowers and trees!
Yea, her all-felt perfection gives the voice
Of the regarded waters to rejoice
Gladlier, and passionates each passing breeze!
Thus in the spirit of prophetic Song
With fearless foot Hell's dread profound along
Trod Milton -- where the lost for ever weep;
And thence upon Uranian pinions strong
Shot sheer -- out into Chaos, whose hoar deep
Its dismal secrets struggling still to keep --
Even as darktorn clouds and surging vapours, greyall,
All wildly writhingCrushed up together, round a whirlwind heap --
Upturned its embryon worlds against him in dismay.
Emerging thence with a rejoicing leap
And soaring -- up, even to Heaven's golden gates,
He through them saw in the eternal clear
Of central peace, all his great Muse relates!
But to return within Creation's sphere
Tow'rds one fair Star, that grew, like Vesper, white,
Then like the Moon -- then vaster, and when near
Because the Earth in her first green delight!
And sothus replenished with creative power,
The EdenParadise of his Vision did he dower
With forms of perfect worth, divine content,
And joys immaculately innocent.
I was once so deeply drowned,
That when the drag my body found,
'Twas void of motion, void of breath,
And, to sensation, dead as Death.
In a languid summer mood,
Lo, I plunge into a flood,
That to the low sun's slanting beams
Gleameth only quiet gleams,
Each one, with a flicker, sheeting
From its still floor -- fast and fleeting.
Such a flood as one would say
Could never, or by night or day,
Have drenched a man's warm life away.
But what are these, down in its bed,
That trail so long and look so red,
Moving as in conscious sport --
Are they weeds of curious sort?

l.add: But

lg.l: But I will dive to them, and see
Into all their mystery.
Down I dive. -- A plenteous crop!
Some shall with me to the top;
For here there is too dim a light
To show their character aright.
I wind them in my arms, intent
To root them up in my ascent.
But they resist me, and again
I tug them with a stronger strain.
Full well, I trow, they hold their own,
Gripping fast each bedded stone
With their rooty tubes, that go
Thence down, through the stiff slime below.
Well, the worst of't is, that I
Must leave them -- But in vain I try!
Fierce as lightning on my brain
Smites the dread truth -- I try in vain!
Yea, more and more, in coils and flakes,
Like long blood-red water snakes,
The deadly things around me clasp,
The more I tug, the more they grasp!
My pent breath, growing hot and thin,
Explodes with a dull-booming din,
While through my unclenched teeth the wave
Comes drenching! Is there none to save?
None near to see -- to guess -- to trace
Under the flood's calm gleaming face,
The dread extremity of one
Thus fastened down? Ah! is there none?
Wild as vain my struggles grow --
Horror! horror! is it so?
Hope gives up her ghost -- Despair!
And as a fish dies in the air,
In its element deep drowned,
I am dying. All around
The long weeds, erst so deeply red,
Look, even where nearest, grey as lead,
As 'mid them, settling down, I sway,
And life keeps bubbling fast away
Through my cold lips, wide agape,
And stiffening into that white shape
They take at last (when done with breath)
In the rigid face of Death.

l.add: And

lg.l: And now, while sullen drummings make
My spirit through mine ears to ake,
Life-long memories strangely fraughtinterwrought
With all I ever felt and thought; --
Sacred fancies, hidden long
Lest the world should do them wrong --
Held back feelings that for years
Iust below the source of tears
Have lain perdu, like gems that bide
In the bright sands unespied,
Over which some Orient stream
Floweth with a golden gleam; --
Taking instantaenous wings,
With a million other things,
All at once -- yet each its own
Shape keeping, -- marked, as if alone --
All, thick inter-thronging, press
Through my drowning consciousness!
All in the same instant so
Do they come and do they go:
Leaving one mixed thought to reign
Sole within my failing brain --
Full of pity, full of pain!
One mixed thought of how my doom
Must wrap my Mother in its gloom;
And give my Sire to hold his breath
For anguish, hearing of my death;
And to allhome-relations be
Always a dread memory;
And overthrowwound one fond heart to the core
In the wide world evermore;
Making Love to her appear
Even when alive and near,
Full of a fate, as full of fear --
Or seen through tears by Memory shed,
But the wild manes of a long dead
Ideal of the soul -- a glow
That, like a sunset, long ago
Went down into the dark of woe.
Lastly, a drear stupor, blent
With a cold cold comfortless content,
Into one mass of clammy clay
Kneads body and mind. Thus drenched away,
With one faint shudder, one last throe,
Life stagnates, and its shell lies low,
Swaying, weed-bound, to and fro,
Void of all feeling, as of breath --
How die we, if this be not Death?
Ah, what thrilling, thrilling pain
Kindles through my heart and brain!
Ah, what horrors, vague and fell,
Come shadowing o'er me, as from Hell!
Ah, those sudden glares of light
They fall like fire-brands on my sight!
Ah, what wast and heavy world
Is all at once upon me hurled,
Massing into one immesne
Oppression, every tortured sense!
Yes: I now remember well
How my sudden fate befell!
And are we then, in death's dread thrall,
Conscious of our funeral?
But where are those who most should mourn
When my bier is graveward borne?
With her whose face I yearn to see --
Where are they? and where is she?

l.add: Where

lg.l: Where the crape-trimmed followers all?
Where the coffin and the pall?
Or do death and nature strive
Within me? Is the drowned alive?
A lonely Boy, far venturing from his home,
With a rude-visaged Herdsman do I roam:
A lonely, wilful Truant, aged eleven,
'Mid rock-browed mountains heaping up to heaven!
Here huge-piled ledges, ribbing outward, stare
Down into haggard chasms; onward there,
The vast-backed ridges are all rent in jags,
Or hunched with cones, or pinnacled with crags!
A rude peculiar world, the Prospect lies
Bounded in circuit by the bending skies.
Now at some stone-rimm'd tank (scooped by the shocks
Of rain-floods leaping from the upper rocks),
Whose liquid disk glows in undimpled rest
Like a vast sapphire on the mountain's breast,
I drink, and muse, -- or mark the wide-spread herd,
Or list the tinkling of the dingle bird;
And now tow'rds some wild-hanging shade I stray,
To shun the bright oppression of the day:

l.add: For

lg.l: For round each crag and o'er each bosky swell
The fierce refracted heat flares visible --
Lambently radiant, like the lustrous hem
Of an else-viewless viel held trembling over them.
A change is felt -- a change that yet reveals
A somewhat only that mere instinct feels.
Why congregate the swallows in the air,
And northward then in rapid flight repair?
Unsettled all at once, and roaming slow
With hands declined, why do the oxen low?
With sudden swelling din, remote yet harsh,
Why roar the bull-frogs in the tea-tree marsh?
Why cease the locusts (*) to throng up in flight
And clap their gay wings in the fervent light?
Why climb they, bodingly demure, instead,
The tallest spear-grass to the bending head?
Instinctively along the sultry sky
I turn a listless yet enquiring eye,
And mark that now, with a most gradual pace
A solemn France keeps creaming o'er its face:

note.p:
What in this country we call the grasshopper, is no
doubt the "locust" of the Bible.

lg.l: Yon clouds that late were laboring past the sun,
Reached by its sure arrest, one after one,
Come to a heavy halt; -- as travellers see
In the wide wilderness of Araby,
A pilgrim horde let even, band by band,
Halting amid the grey interminable sand.
And soon descending with a slumberous weight,
Its sullen influence settles on the great
Heads of the mountains, and the airs that played
About their rugged temples -- all are laid:
While drawing nearer far-off heights appear,
As in a dream's weird prospect -- strangely near!
Till into wood resolves their robe of blue,
And the grey crags come bluffly into view.
-- Such are the signs and tokens that presage
A Summer Hurricane's forthcoming rage.
At length the South sends out her cloudy heaps,
And up the glens a dusky dimness creeps.
The birds, late warbling in the hanging green
Of steep-set brakes, seek now some safer screen --
Skimming in silence o'er the ominous Scene.
The herd in doubt no longer wanders wide,
But, fast in-gathering, throngs yon mountain-side,
Whose echoes, surging to its trampling, seem
Like the gruff mattered troubles of a Titan's dream.
Fast the dun legions of the mustering Storm
Throng denser, or protruding-columns form;
While splashing forward from their cloudy lair,
Convolving flams, like scouting dragons, glare:
Low thunders follow, laboring up the sky;
And as forerunning blasts go blaring by,
At once the Forest bows! -- a mighty stir! --
Bows as in homage to the Thunderer.
Hark! from the wild dogs' blood-polluted dens
In the gloom-hidden chasms of the glens,
Long fitful howls wail up; and in the blast
Strange hissing whispers seem to huddle past,
As the dread stir had wakened from their sleep
Invisible Hags, cave-cloistered in each steep,
who wrapt them in the gloom, and rose amain,
To wanton in the wild-willed Hurricane!
The glow of day is quenched -- expunged the sun
By cloud on cloud dark rolling into one
Tremendous mass of latent thunder, there
Vastly incumbent on the darkening air,
And whose black bosom, as the storm-blast sweeps
Its surface, heaves into enormous heaps,
And seems a pendent ocean to the view,
With weltering whale-like forms all hugely roughened through.
Yet see in the Storm's front, devoid of dread,
How sails you Eagle, like a black flag spread
Before it, -- coming. On his wide wings weighed,
Hardly he seems to move from hence surveyed:
When, far aloft, a bulging mass of gloom
That bends out o'er him, bloating as with doom,
Grows frightfully luminous! Short stops his flight!
His dark form shrivels in the blasting light!
And, as then follows a sharp thunderous sound,
Falls whizzing, stone-like, lifeless to the ground!
Now like a shudder at great Nature's heart
The turmoil grows; and Wonder, with a start,
Detects where Thor right overhead careers,
Girt with black Horrors and wide-flaming Fears!
Arriving thunders, mustering on his path,
Swell more and more the roarings of his wrath,
As out in widening circles they extend --
And then -- at once -- in utter silence end!
Portentious silence! Time keeps breathing past,
Yet it continues! May this marvel last?
Tingles the boding ear; and up the glens
Instinctive dread comes howling from the wild dogs' dens.
Terrific Vision! Heaven's great ceiling splits,
And a vast globe of writhing fire emits,
Which flanking out in one continuous stream,
Spans the black concave like a burning beam
A moment; -- then, from end to end, it shakes
With a quick motion -- and in thunder breaks!
Peal rolled on peal! while heralding the sound,
As each concussion thrills the solid ground,
Fierce glares coil snake-like round the rocky wens
Of the lit hills, or hiss into the glens;
Or thick through heaven like flaming falchions swarm,
Cleaving the cloudy cisterns of the Storm,
From which rain-torrents (searching every gash)
Split by the blast, come sheeting, with a dash
Most multitudinous, -- down through the trees,

And 'gainst the smoking crags that beetle over
these.
Huge fragments, hurrying from its shattered cone,
Wide in the murky air are seen alone!
Huge fragments, upward and around it cast,
Like crude-wing'd, mad-limb's monsters squandering in the blast.
On yon grey Peak, with rock-encrusted roots
The seeming Patriarch of the Wood upshoots,
In whose proud spreading top's imperial height
The mountain Eagle loveth oft to 'light:
Now dimly seen through the tempestuous air,
His form seems harrowed by a mad despair
As with his ponderous arms uptossing high
In each wild blast as it goes shrieking by,
He wrestles with the Storm and threshes at the sky!
But not for long! Up in the lurid air
A swift red bolt is heard to hurtle there --
A dread crash follows! and the Peak is bare!
Huge fragments only, hurrying from it fast,
Are seen, -- or upward or beyond it cast,

Like crude-winged, mad-limbed monsters squandering
in the blast!
The darkness thickens. With despairing cry
From shattered boughs the rain-drenched parrots fly!
Loose rocks wash rumbling from the mountains round,
And half the forest strews the smoking ground!
Stemm'd by the wet crags the blasts wilder moan,
And the caves labor with a ghostlier groan!
Resistless torrents down the gorges flow
With knashing clamours harshening as they go,
And where from cragy bluffs their volumes leap,
Bear with them, -- down, in many a whirling heap,
Those sylvan wrecks that littered late the path
Of the loud Hurricane's all-trampling wrath,
While to their dread percussions, inward sent,
The hearts of the great Hills beat with astonishment!
Strange darings sieze me, witnessing this strife
Of nature's powers; and, heedless of my life,
I stand exposed. And does some fated charm
Hold me secure from elemental harm,
That in the mighty riot I may find
How wide the externality of Mind?(*)

note.p:
(*)This is only partially an after-thought, or an after-thought in
the mode of its expression only, it being founded on the circumstance,
that the author, young as he was, and from the very coming
on of the storm, became possessed with the intention of
eventually describing it, and was thereby led to observe
its startling and dangerous manifestations throughout,
with a singularly daring attention.

lg.l: Yea, through the strikingly apparent see
My secret SoulSpirit'sown soul 's exoteric energy?
Sould wildly drawn abroad -- a Protean force
Clothing with higher life the Tempest in its course!
The Storm is past. Yet booming on afar
Is heard the rattling of Thor's thunder-car,
And the low muffled morning, as of grief,
That follows, with a wood-sigh wide and brief.
The clouds break up; the sun's forth bursting rays
Clothe the wet Landscape with a spangling blaze.
The birds begin to sing a lively strain
And all the milder echoes ring it o'er again.
The clustered herd is spreading out to graze,
Though lesseing torrents still a hundred ways
Flash downward, and from many a tanky ledge
A mantling gush comes quick and shining o'er the edge.
'Tis evening: and the torrents' furious flow
Hath now subsided in the Lakes below.
O'er all the freshened scene no sound is heard
Save the short twitter of some busied bird,
Or a faint rustle, caused amongst the trees
By gusty fragments of a broken breeze.
Round with a heightened buoyancy I stroll,
And a new happiness o'erflows my soul,
While every shady nook and sunny brow
Presents some pleastness unmarked till now.
Thus, when the elements of human life
Burst with an earth-shake into mortal strife,
Wished Peace, returning, like a bird of calm,

Brings to the wounded world, a doubly-valued
balm.

div.head: The Glen of the Whiteman's Grave.

lg.l: I had well-nigh fared through a summer day
O'er rugged mountains that round me lay
Far as a wonder keen eye could strain
Range upon range, -- like a dusky main
Of monster breakers flowing high
And wide along the shoreless sky.
But some upconed, as holding sway
O'er all that round them nearest lay
In tribe like groupes, -- upconed away
And alone in their greatness, like old-world Kings;
High as soar the eagle's wings --
High as the fleecy clouds that play
In the open face of a sunny day.
Such had been my course -- and when
The day was well-nigh ended,
Into a deep and gloomy Glen
The mountain track descended:
A gloomy Glen that far was seen
Winding hugely on between
Two craggy walls that showed the trace
Of many a tempest's wrath --
Hugely on, like a time-hewn path.
For the giant Paw of so wild a place.
And wondrous was the backward view
Thence seen from where the gorge came through.
Huddled together and up-piled,
There was all that's rudely wild;
Nature's most enormous freaks,
Hunching cones and snouted peaks
Ruggeder than e'er were dreamed,
And towering till the blue sky seemed
Torn into fragments by the jags
Of the giant shapen crags.
In this melancholy Glen
Far my feet had fared not, when
In the pathway I might see
Right against me as I came,
Carved deep in the bark of a grand old tree
A fatal-fortuned name!
'Twas The name of a murdered man! and I
Many a time by the bush-fire side,
Had heard his story with a sigh,
And a boding look o'er the dim descried
And savager haunts that, haply, lay

l.del: Where the wild view in the distance grew grey
l.add: Where the wild prospect, cloud enskied,
Dropped as it were away

lg.l: Wherefore, I turned me from the road
With a sympathetic load
At heart, and with a rueful face,
To find his Grave in that lonesome place.
That evening! never knew I one
More solemn browed. The great round sun
O'er the lit summits crowded vast
Against the West, was sinking fast.
A few grey cloudlets-shreds only were
Seen in the vault of heaven to stir,
As [hanging ivy locks]cobwebs, dim and torn, might wave
From the marble dome of a mighty cave.
A gust at measuredfitful intervals
Fell over the nearer mountain walls,
And then with a sound like the motion of snakes
Rustled away through the rounding brakes,
Or lingered, as it were to pine
In the twilight top of the turpentine
Its own low dirge -- a dying tone
In the turpentine's dense top alone.
And once a dusky eagle came
In solemn travel o'er the same
Steadily straight, as from afar
Came over, -- but the airy jar
Of his wide wings in swept decrease
Soon faded, as with upward sweep
He passed beyond the opponent steep --
And all around was perfect peace:

l.add: Yea, so perfect as to be
Even frightful, through extremity!
Yea, so perfect as to seem
Even imminent, through mere extreme!

lg.l: And now the sought-for Grave I found.
Against me stretched, its lonely mound
Was darkly seen, and by degrees,
In the broken shade of the silent trees;
Till, on a sudden, a last glance rayed

l.add: From

lg.l: From the setting sun for a moment played
O'er it, and then backward ran,
As Hope's last flickering gleam might fade
From the face of a doomed man.
Only one tuft of grass did wave
Above that sterile desert Grave
Bestrewn with leaves and withered sprays,
And only one blue flower did gaze
Timidly up, as near I trod,
From between'twixt the dry lips of a broken clod.
Oh, 'twas a desolate, dreary thing,
That Grave in the else-green lap of Spring --
In the else-unbroached primeval sod!
As I looked on it then through a starting tear,
And the feeling -- Alas! for the Sleeper here,
In a Grave like the first of its kindthat first in the world --, O God!
That first bleak scar in the Earth's new mould
Ridged upThat clasedstretched over Abel in Eden of old,
Ere the spirit ofSpring's healing, thoughafter many a year,
Had flowered it with purple and gold!
I would not -- I would not one human child

l.add: Of

lg.l: Of the earth should be laid in the lonely cold
Of a Grave so wild!
Thus deep -- sea-deep, was the pity I felt
For the fate of the lonely dead;
Till moved, as it seemed, by a spirit of dread
That gathered around in the gloom,
Down in that lonesome place I knelt
By the side of the lowly tomb.
And kneeling thus alone, I drew
His Image on that evil day
When there first coming on the view
Of Felons bent to slay.
A visionary Youth, methought,
On he came all wonder-wrought
With the dreary grandeur mass'd
Round himAloft in shapes so wild and vast,
And which his memory oft compared,
For contrast, with the rural joy
Of scenes in England where he had fared
The MostOftenOft'nest when a happy Boy --
Scenes glad with loving voices then!
And not like thosethesethose in this drear Glen
Which nowthounow his wandering vision saw!
All silent, or but fitfully
Bestarted, when some loud macaw
Might send abroad his doleful cry:
A sound that waiteth through the air
Like an utterance of Despair,
Or of Sorrow mourning high
As she is wont in lonely places,
Where but her own wild shade she chases,
And no comforter is nigh.
Thus his Image passed before
My fancy -- till it changed the scene,
And through its geographic lore
Dreaming, sailed the seas between
The Antipodes -- those world-wide seas
Stretched out between the Antipodes!
And onward thence -- and onward, o'er
The navy-laden waves that roar
Along the Anglic coast, to seek
For objects there whereon to wreak
The burthen of its lonely ruth --
A Sire of the same name,
With her who bare that doomed Youth,
A sorrow pallid Dame.
Both I pictured old and grey,
And bent with mourning many a day --
Mourning hopelessly for one
Their age had cherished, and in whom
Even through the sacred tie of son,
They ha'd seen again their beings bloom!
But saw not, as they blest him then,
A lonely Grave in a gloomy Glen,
Thought I, recurring to its gloom; --
Even this dusk glen -- and this lone mound
With savage mountains rampired round!
And whereon, yonHere! where the new cleft clods between,
The nameless flower of a nameless scene
So meekly rears its lonesome head!
Here! where a kindred creature's tread
Comes but to wake a haggard cry
Of wonder in the wild dog's lair,
The Living's sole abode; and where
The Black even, seldom ventures nigh,
Nor dares to halt: but striding fast,
And, calling them close, points out to his boys
What suddenly hushes their thoughtless noise --
The Whiteman's Grave! then hurries past!
And thinking thus of him who slept

l.del: There, and of those who even then
l.add: After his morning taste of time,
In that wild mountain bay, and kept
Memorial even there of Crime.
And of those who even then

lg.l: Might mourn that Sleeper of the Glen,
A brother's sorrow o'er me crept,
And seeing I might vainly try
To keep mine eyelids longer dry,
I groveled by the Grave, and wept:
Such tearsYea, wept as we are glad to weep
When some great load is on the brain,
As given by Nature so to keep
The saddest thinking sane,
And sweet for future use, I trow,
When we shall understand at length,
What beauty of soul, and grace to know,
And wisely sympathetic strength,
Was born to us of Woe:
Wept, until clouding up the Glen
The dark came, following the grey
Withdrawing skirts of parted day --

l.add: And thinking thus of him whose sleep
his morning taste of time,
In that else primeval waste did keep
Dread memories, even there, of Crime!
And of those who even afar, who then
Might mourn that Sleeper of the Glen,

lg.l: And deepened was my spirit when
I sped at last away.
Go Sympathy, best mate of Grief,
To all who mourn him waft relief:
For thou hast much to give, dear elf,
To others in extremity,
Even when thou hast for thy own self
Little -- or nothing it may be!
Thy sweet sad smiles some lightness
Can bring the weariest heart,
And thy lustrous tears some brightness
To the gloomiest soul impart:
As wreaths of flowers are soothing
Unto a dying child --
As the moon's beams come smoothing
O'er some benighted wild.

Hath graven on the giant crag-boned mountains,
And wild sea shores, dim dells, and watery chasms,
And in the deeps downdeath-dark bowels of the Earth,
We learn that she, at dateless intervals,
Hath been the plastic and predestined mould
Of awfullest changes; and, in eras vast,
The fecund mother of successive births

(Even as beheld in thought, and from so far)
Have swarmed o'er all her clammy disc, like worms
Clothing a corpse; or beings unto which
The monstrous serpent of the Indian waste
Were but a minim, in her miry breast

Beings enormous! -- but to perish, when

lg.l: For things of greater beauty. Whether wrought
Into such meetness by a law of change,
For ever active, and thence through all time
Distributing its force; or by the sweep
Of sudden cataclysms, wild and vast;
Or by the outburst of internal fires,
Instant and universal.
[Out of wide watery levels] First emerged
Mountains abrupt, like those upon the Moon,
Scarred through with fissures out of which there seethed
A white volcanic heat, while spongy growths
Of cypress dark and flowerless forests, filled
Vast valleys with a damp and noisome shade,
But luminous at intervals with drear
And waveless lakes, that took the shadowing bulk
Of bat-like monsters flying overhead;
Or, from their shores projecting, glassed the huge
Unwieldy masses of some mammoth herds
As into the dim spaces of the dense
And bordering woods it passed, and onward then
Crashed, munching as it went. And yet on this
So lonesome scene, the sun arose, as now,
True to his season, and the moon unveiled
Her pale face over it night after night,
Bevied about with all her golden train
Of stellar glories raying influence down.
Yea, thus, for countless centuries, beneath
The sun and moon and stars, did all the bare
And slopeless hills show ghastly in their light,
And the dull waters gleam: although as yet,
Through all those patient periods immature,
No soul intelligent, save God alone,
Might know them, --asas God their great maker, -- GodHe alone
In [manifestjubilant ascension, Lastly, Man,
And all the tribes of creatures over which
He reigneth absolute, with comelier forms
Of higher mould; and inwardly indued
With spirits and with faculties to endsthat flourished forth

Then on the hills the hunter's voice went forth,
And, in the valleys, the glad chaunt of birds
Chimed sweetly with the gurgling interflows,
And musical motions, manifold and mixed,
Of rivers, and wide depths of bloomy boughs
All billowing in the breeze; and echoes housed
In rocky steeps, and caves, and twilight dells,
Made merry with the cheerful noise that came
Mellowed by distance, out of lowing glens,
And bleating vales, -- all lying in each broad
Allotted heritage that stretched around
The low roofed homesteads of an early world,
Bosomed in trees from which ripe golden globes
Hung clustered, while aroundaboutthem rippled deep
Glad fields of rustling corn: till Nature taught
Music to Art, and Poesy arose
Out of the dayspring like a morning star
Upon the awakened spirit of delight;
And Form, idealised in hues, or wrought
From the rude rock into a life which spake
The language of immutable loveliness,
Adorned the abodes of Learning; -- sister Arts,
Three sister Arts in fellowship divine --
A triune glory of exalted soul!
But dare we think the awful Law of Change,
From good to better, hath even hereyet an end?
That Earth is Man's for ever? -- his and theirs,
The tribes o'er which, preeminent, he reigns
As King? -- his only Kingship! No: the Hours
That shall behold her the prepared abode
For new successions in the scheme of life,
May even now (like a long flight of storks
Far looming into view) be winging up
Their dim but destined way amid the clouds
That hide the pregnant Future in their pregnant folds.
But, granting this, from whence, it But from whencemay be asked
Might spring these novel Orders? From the womb
Prolific of that Spirit of the Earth
Which men call Fate, and where, even from the first,
In virtual preparation shall have slept
Their causes, darkling -- but awaiting there
The evoking word of God; expressed through laws
Which are in their results but the produced
Decisions of his will. Or rather, they
AreWere but progressive changes in the sum
And increment of that divine Idea,
Whereof the Earth's so solid-seeming bulk
Is, with its fleshly populations whole,
The vesture -- yea, the tactical outward shape
And visual sign in manifold reflexion;
As ever forth fulfilling, more and more,
Its part in that great order which attests
The prospering intercourse of all the worlds:
Iust as a human thought (so far as what
Is finite, and imperfect therefore, may
With infinite compare), -- as knowledge grows
Before it, and combined all cognatecongruent things,
A necessary progress undergoes
In its accruing unity with Truth.
But come what changes may, yet is the Soul,
As individualised in all mankind,
Beyond the swoop of chance, and lifted high
Out of the crash of matter! She, complete
In her sole being, evermore aspires,
An ultimate of all that went before --
A Spirit of Thought, and thence a child of that
In which the world began and hath its end;
And thus derived, -- a Virtue purer far
Than that invisible, ethereal fire --
That vital energy thatwhich breathes abroad
Through Nature's boundless lungs, -- she cannot know
Or darkness or corruption, but must be
A missioned Liberty, and thence endued
With powers of self development that break
All bondage! Thus, ancestrally a spark
From God's internal brightness, goes she forth
To die not, but to clothe for evermore
Her mighty life and wondrous faculties
In robes of beauty and of use, and all
The comforting integuments that sense
Weaves for her wearing, in the loom of Time,
Out of the hoards and harvests of the Earth;
And thence by transmigrations made through that
New birth which takes death's semblance, in the worth
And garniture of many or all of those
Innumerable other worlds, that strew
The neighbouring heavens with seats of being, such
As host on host, yet farther forth, enrich
Infinite spaces, populous alike
With kindred glories [referent to]that exist in Him!
As being but the million-featured modes
Of his star seeming Thoughts; -- each several thought
A shining link in one eternal chain
Of progress -- to Perfection. Here we rest.
"The poor Whiteman, faint and weary,
Came and sat under our tree.
He has no mother to bring him milk --
No wife to grind his corn.

lg.l: Behold an Indian Isle, reposed
Upon the Deep's enamoured breast,
Even like a royal bride be-rosed
With passion in her happy rest.
Or while the Morn is there disclosed,
[Or Evening robes her in the west,]
The Deepspread out in one wide circuit rolled, -- wide
And round as heaven from side to side,

l.add: The Deep, as by that Isle embossed
With central gauds of sumless cost,
And spread else outspread in circuit -- wide
And round as heaven from side to side

lg.l: And midward by that isle embossed
As with a stuff of rarer cost,
Might figure to a fancy bold
Like a vast shield of fretted gold,
Dropt by some elder God, as he worsted Elder God,

l.del: Passed worsted on in his eternity.
l.add: When on his track, where'er he trod,

lg.l: Iove's chasing thunders rolled.
Or in the broad Noon domed with heaven,
A world-wide Temple's marble floor
It seemeth, with one Altar graven
From the rude mass of things ,
By Time inspired with Eden lore:
An isle-like Altar, sculptured o'er
With craggy hills, and valleys green,
And heaping forests hung between:
By Time, with an old love enthralled,
Wrought thus in living emerald;
And after Nature's earliest style
Is all the work -- that Indian Isle.
Or circling out beneath the moon,
Or sowed with all the stars of night,
And by the lamp-like planets strewn
With broadlong inflaming bars of light,
Might seem it to a fancy fond
Grey Time's broad seal of diamond,
Enchased by Nature, memory-taught,
With one most rich and rare device --
A lingering insulated thought
Of her sin-ruined Paradise.
A Summer Island: there the trees
Of glorious forms unseen elsewhere,
Hang forth in golden
Their fruit through all the purple year;
And flowers of every sunset hue,
And peerless plants of stateliest stem,
Fresh showered each morn with hony dew,
Voluptuoswly impave and gem
The pillary aisles of primal groves
That skirt the sunny sea-board coves,
Or hang in their umbrageous crowds
From coasting slopes like verdant clouds:
While from the craggy midland hills,
Out of their gelid springs, the rills,
Leap, as exulting to be free,
And thence in their bright liberty
Through glens and cultured valleys vast,
And many a wide pastured lea,
Come, murmurously winding, fast
And flashing to the sea.
There too, what birds on plain and mountain,
The fairest creatures of the earth,
As deepest dipt in Beauty's fountain
By their ultra-summer birth,
Swarm round, and vividly unfold
Their fulgent wings of feathery gold
Bedropt with gem-like lustres, streaming
In their swift flight, and interbeaming.
Thus swarm they, and with splendors rare
Emblaze the warm and genial air.
Such is the Summer wealth and worth
Of that bright Isle I'd picture forth:
Nor wants it fields that well afford
The yellow grain and mellow gourd;
Nor many a cultivated plain
Prolific of the luscious cane,
And mealy root: for all things there
Are bounteous in their kind , and fair,
And genial; -- all but the bad mind
Of recreant Man! and that hath made
Its very beauty seem designed
To deepen Evil's deadly shade;

l.add: (As to such contrast there confined)

lg.l: And given its repute to be,
As borne abroad by every wind
That wafts a white sail o'er the sea,
Even like the saviour (thick with doom)
Of some o'ergorged though costly tomb!
Oh! Learn how like a Upas Tree,

lg.l: Can make a scene that else might tell
Of Paradise, a type of Hell!
'Twas Eve -- and a long tremulous cry
Had sunk to low sobs, thin and dry,
(EVen such as are the poor relief
Of age and sickness clothed in grief)
After the loud and dinning spite
Of oaths and whips had ceased to fright
The soft wind that was ruffling through
The greenest crops that ever grew,
Save in that Isle so summer-bright!
When through an orange hedge unclept
And old and haggard Negro slept
With feeble haste, as he in fear
Would hide from some pursuer near,
More dreadful to his though than death!
But unpursued, and taking breath,
Thus with his story did he stir
The soul of a pitying
Master, thou seemest sad to see
These bleeding stripes -- my misery!
Are they deserved because no more
My failing vigor now can bear
With agile step and willing air
The load it once so freely bore?
Nor ply with these age-shrunken arms --
Now that the blood so thinly warms
This withered heart of care,
The wearying hoe as it was wont
When I was younger in despair?
How dare you cruel men account
That God hath made me Man -- and they
Being men, yet mock Him day by day --
Him and themselves! in loading so
With direst wrong and bitterest wo --
With every suffering that they can
A Man -- an old and broken man!
Thou pitiest me -- and I have longed
In vain for pity many a year;
'Tis very precious to the wronged,
And to the Slave 'tis doubly dear:
'Tis sweeter to his heart than rest
Is to his weary limbs, opprest
With toil through the long scorching day.
And gentle Sir, since they haply they,
My drivers, will no more molest
My wasted nature with their spite
So wantonterrible, till to-morrow's light
Shall re-awaken Grief and me,
Couldst thou afford the time to one
Thus abject -- now, even while the sun
Drops o'er the burning waves, to thee
I'd tell how grew this misery.
I thank thee, Master; -- sit thou hear
Upon this bank. -- I am very old,
And dead and gone is many a year,
(The lost count must remain untold)
Since in my own far Country, near
My little orphan children twain,
I sat before our Hut of cane,
Which clung as twere to the ancient wood
Where once my Tribe's chief village stood: --
Methinks I see myself again
There sitting with my children twain,
Full in the pleasant evening breeze!
That Hut my dwelling long had been;
'Twas joisted in four living trees
That met aloft, high o'er the roof
In domes of solid shade sun-proof,
And from its wicker door the sheen
Of one clear brook might just be seen,
Or, if you listened, just be heard
Its mellow bubble, where 'twas stirred
From underneath by pebbles strown
About the bed, and thence upthrown
The margin reeds between;
Or when it made a murmurous moan
Over a ledge of mossy stone,
And which, so lonely 'twas and low,
Did ever, to the heart's relief,
Touch Memory with some gentle grief,
As always in its hidden flow
'Twere babbling of the long ago:
While from betwixt two trellised lines
Of large leafed intertwisting vines,
On which bright cooling berries grew
Like clustered drops of golden dew,
Far over slopes of forest green --
Far as might range the wondering eye,
The vast uprising Main was seen
To meet the bending sky.
Twelve moons before my Wife had died,
And I at length had grown to have
No hope, nor wish, nor joy beside
What now her living loved ones gave
My heart, that else had dwelt in gloom
As buried in their Mother's tomb.
And as I thought of this, with tears, --
The showers of a concealed distress,
Fast trickling from my palm-hid cheek --
(Oh, there's a grief itself endears
By its own very loneliness,
And love is aye both strong and weak!)
Behold, upon a wayside stone
Within the unbroken shadow thrown
Far outward by our household trees,
A seaward coming Whiteman moiled
With travel, and with dust besoiled,
Did seat him in the evening breeze;
And shaking out his sweat-damp hair,
He seemed to hunger, sitting there.
And so I led (as closed the day)
My wondering Children forth, that they
Might with me for the Stranger feel,
And bid him to our evening meal.
"We have enough for all," I said,
"And some to spare, wherewith to stay
Thy need through all to-morrow's way.
Delay not, -- come, and still with bread
The heart's pine when 'tis hunger's prey.
With kindly hospitable pride
My Girl shall wash they fretted feet;
In soothing measures at thy side
My Boy shall sing a ditty sweet:
How once a wanderer had died
Of famine in the desert wide,
But that his Mother found him there
And saved him by her gentle care.
Learn hence my daughter ne'er to let
The stranger pass in his despair,
It help it thy best welcome can --
Thy brother may be wandering yet
A solitary man.
And know that I, in days of yore,
When wandering weary and alone
Thus sat before thy Mother's door
While from the brook she heaved her can --
Even thus upon a wayside stone,
A solitary man."
The Whiteman at my bidding rose
And followed; while my children went
Before, the wicket to unclose,
On hospitality intent.
Arriving there, the girl and boy
Shouted for charitable joy;
Then turned them, our regard to win,
And smile their Father's quest within.
Now plenteous was the meal I spread
Before him, with a pleasant air,
And heartily the Stranger fed,
And heartily he praised our fare.
And when he was sufficed, I threw
Our softest mat upon the floor,
That he might stretch him there and rue
The long day's weary weight no more.
And flattered much were we to see
The comfort and complacency
Which seemed his jaded sense to shroud
As in a shadowing summer cloud,
While breathing yet more deep and deep,
He sanksunk into the depths of sleep:
When softly in my bended ear
My daughter slid these words of fear.
"The Whiteman sleeps: his face how fair!
Yet some dread shade seems o'er it hung --
The token or of wrong or care,
Or secret hate. He looks but young,
And yet his strange unfizzled hair
In long flakes from his forehead flung,
Is flecked throughout with lines of grey
Like darkness at the dawn of day;
And see, at times, -- yea, even now,
How fiercely lours his knotted brow,
As through his dreams werewent thundering o'erfast
Dark memories of a stormy yore!Past
Thus she: and then my boy, as nigh
The couch he watched, this lullaby
Sang softly: -- "Rest thee, Stranger, -- rest!
Thy need is past and friends are near;
No longer by the heat opprest,
Sleep, nor consent to dream in fear
Of the remorseless tiger here!
Sleep, till the first shot glance of day morn
Inflame the dews on every thorn,
And from the sun-enkindled sea
The earliest airs come bracingly."
Then I -- "And when thou dost depart,
Thus rested, on thy desert track,
Three ample meals, to cheer thy heart,
Shall store the wallet at thy back;
And still before thee, strong in love,
May the Good Spirit's presence move,
Preventing every shape of wrath
And danger on thy lonely path;
And when thou hungerest again
Upon the dry unyielding plain,
Even to thy wish, mayst thou descry
Some hospitable village nigh;

l.add: And

lg.l: And when from thirst thy strength shall flag,
May fresh wing's breezes round the bring
A cool and constant murmuring
Of waters from some fissured crag
Down slipping into mossy tanks --
Or brimming from their shaded well,
Or winding out of some dim dell
Into a rill with willowywillowy banks."
But when we too, on mats spread out,
In Sleep's descended cloud reclined,
Strange fattering fears, -- a troublous rout,
Kept peopling my prophetic mind.
I dreamt of Her that I had lost,
Who stealthily, methought, drew nigh
And fixed me with her mournful eye --
Till on a sea-like trouble tossed,
I wept, though dimly wondering why.
Still, as I slumbered, many Forms
Moved round me, or kept hovering o'er,
And voices that belonged of yore
To kindred gathered to the worms,
Even when I started from my dream,
Did from the dark yet sounding seem.
And closer too, than wont, my boy
Clung to his boding sire that night --
His little dreams were not of joy,
For he would shudder with affright,
Whene'er in louder gusts the breeze
Swept through the overdoming trees!
At length I slept -- too soundly! Cries
Were wildly shrilling in min ears,
And yet I could not wake; mine eyes
Seemed on their loaded lids to bear
The burthen of a thousand years
Of weariness and care!
Till rude hands grasped me! Woke I then --
Alas! to see my children bound!
To see six tiger visaged men
All fiercely pressing round!
While he -- our Guest, was standing near
The unmasked leader of the crew!
Yea, he, in payment for our cheer,
The wrong they did us, bade them do!
In vain I knelt in suppliant fear,
And bathed his feetknees with many a tear;
He dashed me down upon the floor!
And thriving with a demon sneer,
To see my front all red with gore,
He bade his villains drag is where
Within a mangrove shrouded bay,
Like a sea monster in its lair
His lurking vessel lay, --
Distant three lonely leagues or more,
And whence, like wolves, the day before
He and his gang had prowled for prey.
The rest is brief: they sold us here --
They tore the father from the child!
And cursed them for their shrieks so drear,
And scourged them for their grief so wild!
Nor have I, all the weary years
That I have drenched in Slavery's tears,
Learned whither went my boy, nor where
My daughter dwelt in her despair,
Nor whether, unredeemed by death,
They yet may draw life's toilsome breath.
But he -- our base Enslaver! (this
His shipmates shuddered aye to tell,
As if their memories then did hiss
Within them like the snakes of Hell!)
Next visiting the Afric coast,
One morning, ghastly as a ghost,
After a dread debauch, wherein
Wild Riot led the dance of Sin,
Rose raging, murder-mad, and slew
With sudden onslaught half his crew!
And through the rest with chains of strength
Did both him to the deck at length,
Amid the slaughtered in their gore;
Vain were all fetters! With a roar
Wild as a wounded pard's, he wrenched
His gyves, as they had been no more
Than yarns of flax; -- the hoop unclenched
From round his trunk -- the bolts uptore --
Leaped from the deck, and tow'rds the shore,
Though by the thundering surge deep drenched,
Swam shouting! -- made the beach and fled
Into the tangled jungles spread
Immensely inland, -- where, 'tis said,
Even the mighty lion blenched
Before the howling fratricide,
As day and night with eyes of fire
On, on he roamed, nor seemed to tire,
Till hunger clung him and he died.
Fit end, though terrible and sad,
For one so violently bad
Even in its his wits -- if ever sane
We may account the sons of Cain!
And he (for so the story ran)
Was born amongst a pirate crew,
And cradled in their bark;
And ever, up from boy to man,
More wildly fierce his nature grew,
His deeds more direly dark!
Boldly he compassed what he planned,
And boldly could the the bad command;
For nothing in the world thought he
Or worth his heed or rivalry,
But wrong and riot on the land,
And storm and battle on the sea.
My Tale is told: nor more for me
Remaineth, but to hunger more
Than withered Famine doth for food,
And more to thirst than even he
Who journeyeth tongue-swollen o'er
Some wide unwatered solitude,
For that sure heaven-appointed day
Which soon shall break my bonds away!
It comes! -- and from it all my vast
Heaped misery, shall, even like a grey
And spectral mist before the Hast,
Melt scattering! -- Why doth it delay
To give me to the pangless Past?
Yet grieve not, Master, that mine eyes
Are now thus wet; -- these tears are sweet,
For from a soothed heart they arise
As thanks for thy sweet kindness meet.
And never -- never mayst thou need
Ere God shall sheild thee in the grave,
Such pity as thou hast shown indeed
So freely to a Slave.
'Tis nine o' clock -- to bed! cried Egremont,
Who, with his youthful household, long ago,
(The sturdy father of seven sturdy boys)
Dwelt in a lone Home nested far within
Our virgin Forest, that scarce broken then,
As with an unshorn fleece of gloomy wood
Robed the vast bulk of all the mighty Isle.
But ere retiring finally, he went
Forth as his wont was to survey the night.
'Twas clear and silent: and the stirless woods
Looked dreaming in the witch-light of the Moon,
As, like a boat of stained pearl, she rode
Dipping, it seemed, with a propendent motion,
Amid the ridges of a wavy cloud --
The only cloud in heaven: round which afar,
The larger stars out of the depths of space
Hung pendulous, trembling with a glow globose --
So keenly clear the night. And while our Friend
Looked thus abroad observingly abroad, he marked
All round him, listing the horizon's verge,
A broad unusual upward glaring gleam --
Such a drear raidance as the setting sun
Effuses when the atmosphere is stormy.
What this might be he wondered -- but not long;
Divining soon the cause -- a vast Bush Fire!
But deeming it too distant yet for harm,
During the night betiding, to repose
With his bed-faring household he retired.
Sound was their sleep: for honesty of life
Is somewhat lumpish when 'tis once a-bed.
And now the darkness of the night was past,
When with the dreams of Egremont, a strange
And momently approaching roar began
To mingle, and insinuate through them more
And more of its actual import -- till a Fire
Huge in imagination as the world,
Was their sole theme: then, as arising wild,
His spirit fled before its visioned fear,
He started from his sleep -- and found indeed
The hardly (it seemed) exaggerated type's
Conflagrant hugeness, from abroad derived
In warning! for what else, however terrible,
Save ocean snoring to a midnight storm,
Might breathe with a vitality at once
As that So universal, strenuous, and fierce which reigned without so roaringly without(whate'er it was) reigning, lapped and roared without!
Upleaping from his couch, Scare did he wait
To clothe himself, ere forth he rushed, -- and lo,
Within the circling forest he beheld
A vast and billowy belt of writhing fire,
That shed a wild and lurid splendor up
Against the whitening dawn, come raging on!
Raging and roaring as with ten thousand tongues
That prophesied destruction! On it came,
A dreadful apparition! -- such as Fear
Concieves when dreaming of the front of hell!
No time was there to lose. Up -- up! he cried
To all the house! Instantly all within
Was hate and wonder, and in briefest space
The whole-roused family was staring out
In speechless admiration! Yea, in that
Wild sympathetic union with the Terrible,
Which in the sudden and unlooked-for midst
Of a tremendous danger, oft ensues,
And, for a time, keeps through its own mere extreme
Keeps terror dormant. But more urgently
The voice of Egremont again was heard; --
Lose not a moment! Follow me at once,
Each with whatever he can grasp of use,
And carry unincumbered, as he flies!
Out from the doorway, Right before them, lo,
A narrow-strip of clearing, like a glade,
Stretched outon tow'rds a bald summit. Thitherward
The perilled people now were hurrying all;
While in their front, beneath the ridge, a dense
Extent of dead brush into which the Fire's
Bright teeth were ravening, -- near, and nearer, brought
The rapid danger! Shall they reach that hill
Unscathed, their only refuge? Will they speed
Past the red-rushing exigence! And lo,
As thus they hurry on, how more and more
Disclosing spectre-like from the red gloom,
And brushing through them with long whizzing bounds,
The Kangaroos string forth in Indian file
Across that strip of clear; with here and there
A wild dog slinking rapidly along
Amid the general rout, human and brute!
Thus passingly involved, yet onward rush
Our people -- urged into a desperate pace
By the hot glare that now comes sweltering round,
And the loud roar that loudens all along
The line of their wild flight, as if the flames
Were wrathful at their prospect of escape
And hurried also -- hurried with a swoop,
And raged more ruinously while they weened
To intercept, and blast them! -- But at length
The grass-bald border of the summit's gained,
Even as the Fire, upon the left hand, breaks
Against the hill's base like a ruddy surge;
And hatting, they look back -- in safety all,
Though scorched and breathless, and begrimed with heat & smoke
But lo! no sooner had they crowding passed
Out from the brush, where into a broad dell
It dipped on all hands round a sullen pool,
And where the rank and withered runners lay
In tangled heaps, -- than a vast swath of flame
Lifted and gurried forward by the wind
Over their very passage track, was pitched
Sheer into it, with a loud thud like thunder --
With such a thud as the sea-swell gives up
From under the ledges of some hanging cliff;
And, in an instant, all the wide sere depth
Was as a lake of Hell! And hark! as then
Even like a ghastly pyramid the mass
Of wide-spread flames, inlapping as they rose
And welding as it were all into one
Dense pile, rushed lancing up, -- up with them still
A long mad shriek of mortal agony went
Writhing aloft! -- so terrible indeed,
That those who heard it, never, until then,
Might deem a voice so earnest in its fear,
So strenuous in its anguish, could have being
In the live bosom of the normalsuffering world!
But soon did they divine, even to their loss,
Its import: -- there a giant steed, their best,
Had vainly taken cover, there to diebut to perishso there!
Sheltered Tented with heaven only -- butAll grouped
In safety now upon that hill's bare top --
Egremont and his household looked abroad
Astonished at the terrors of the time!
Down sunk their rooftree in the surging Fire;
Which entering next a high-grassed bottom, thick
With barkaxe-ringed trees * all standing bleak and leafless,
Tenfold more terrible in its ravage grew,
Upclimbing to their tops! And soon, as when
Upon some day of national festival,
From the tall spars of the ship-crowded poet,
Innumerous flags, in one direction all,
Tongue outward, writhing in the wind; even so,
From those dry boles where still the dead bark clings
Hanging in ragged strips half shelled away,
And from their multifarious mass above
Of withered boughs, myriads of flaming tongues
Lick upward, or aloft, in narrowing flakes,
Stream out, -- and thence, upon the tortured blast,
Bicker and flap, and mix inconstantly,
As inAllInto one wide though multifariousmanifold blaze.

lg.l: Comes whizzing, and then sweeping low, alights
In a gay-colored crowd amid the oaks
Stretched inThat like a feathery fringe along the base
Of yon steep terrace, being (as it seems)
Deterred from still proceeding by the smoke
Uprolled in front, heap ridging over heap,
Like a dim-moving range of spectral mountains.
There they abide, and listen in their fear
To the tremendous riot of the flames
That out beyond the range come billowing fast
Though yet unseen from thence, -- till, with a hoarse
And pouncing swoop as of a hurricane,
Furiously siezing on the drouth-sered brakes
That shag the terrace (littered thick with leaves
And resinous grass-tree stubs, and dense throughout
With sun-dried woodvines,) all their serpent shapes
Rush upward, and then culminating, bend
Sheer o'er the oaks wherein the birds are lodged.
All are in flight at once, but from above
As suddenly, a mightier burst of flame
Outsheeteth o'er them! Down they dip -- but it
Keeps swooping with them even to the ground,
Drawn thither by dead wood-drifts, layer on layer
There lodged, as rain swept from the heights above --
And where, a moment after, all are seen
To writhe convulsed -- blasted and plumeless all!
Out in the Forest looming through the smoke
Where dim and most like, farthest forth it rolls,
Behold how furiously a horseman comes!
Sent from the nearest station, though thus late,
To warm our people of the mighty Fire
Ere haply it reached them; -- telling them in time
How there, so lately, its red waves had brought
Sudden destruction, and wide loss, -- and then
Surged on illimitably through the woods,
Bearing right hitherward! Bravely on he steers
To where the fronting flames from either hand
Are closing to a gap! No other way,
All round, is open; and he nears it -- But
Too late, alas! or so to those it seems
Who watch him from the clear! Too late! for lo,
The lines of fire (ere 't seemed they would) have met,
And man and horse are swallowed out of sight
In one red gloom of mingled flame and smoke!
But for a moment only. Bursting forth,
As if developed from that lurid mass,
The noble hackney brings his rider through,
All but unsinged! Our friends hurrah! and he
Soon joins them -- welcome, though too late to help.
Thus through the day the conflagration raged:
And when the wings of night o'erspread the scene,
Not even they, with all their world-wide pomp
Of starry blazoury, wore such a live.
And aggregated glory to the eye,
As did the blazing dead wood of the forest --
On all hands blazing! Yet, far off, the dells
Lay like black gouts amid the general view
Of glimmering heights, which through the red light showed
Like some imaginary waste of Hell
Painted in blood! But nearer, all the scene
Was frightfully brilliant. From vast hollow trunks
Whose ponderous heads, in some great hurricane,
Where the bole narrowed had been swept away,
The wild fire, with a sudden roar, would burst
In quivering columns chapitered with smoke
Half turned itself into a lurid glow,
As out of craters; or some carious bough,
The white heat seething from its spouty flaws,
Would, with a dread crash, from the hill-top trees
(Massing aloft over the gleamy dark
That shut in under a high hanging steep)
Swoop flaming, like an upsphered group of stars,
Torn and disfeatured in their ruinous fall,
And run together, -- a swift dropping mass
Of luminous points and flaring limbs that met
All in one fiery train, back streaming, -- till
It shattered as it struck the blackened vale
Into a cloud of upward rushing sparks,
And igneous dust! Or down the flickery glades
Ghastfully glaring, huge dry-mouldered gums
Stood mid their living kindred barked with fire!
Boles, branches, -- all! like ominous ghosts of trees, --
The Wood's first fathers wrapt in burning shrouds,
Come from the past, within the Whiteman's pale,
To typify its doom. Such was the prospect!
Illuminated cities were but jists
Compared with it for splendor. But enough!
Where are the words to paint the million shapes
And unimaginable freaks of Fire,
When holding thus its monster carnival
In the primeval Forest all night long?

lg.l: Lost in the Bush! -- the night approaching fast,
And around loudening a cold-breathing blast!
Fancy the thing! Then mark how settler Will
There, in the pathless Forest, stands stock-still,
With keen heed questioning yon peculiar hill,
Only to win from it this answer -- "Yea,
I tell thee, stranger, thou hast gone astray!"
Thus answered, back he turns, intent to find
Some prospect more familiar to his mind;
But vainly! for the farther back he goes,
The backward scene itself yet stranger grows!
So that he mutters, while he scans the ground,
"By Iove, the very world seems twisted round!
And you red gleam on the horizon yet,
Is where, methinks, the sun should rise -- not set!
Then, with a sudden wheelspin, the anxious swain
Turns, just to question that blunt again,
Which was the first to tell him that for once
His shrewd bush-instinct had turned out a dunce.
But which is which? A dozen summits lie
As like as eggs against the twilight sky,
And it amongst them! With a blank surprise
His mouth drops open and wide stare his eyes!
Then squats he on his hams, intent to gain
Yet clearer views: but clearer views are vain!
The pleasant fact abides through every test:
And drawing a long breath, he mutters "Well, I'm blest!"
In short, he's lost. And seeing that the night
Will be a wild one, he (as well he might)
Scratches his head and much that member loads
With execrations: "What! forego the roads
For shorter cuts so near the day's decline,
'Mongst hills and bushes? -- Drat this head o' mine!
The dark is settling round as thick as mire!
The Bush too's roaring like a world on fire!
I am not one much given to foolish tirrits,
And far too knowing to believe in Spirits;
But such a night in such a cursed place
Might almost put one in a raving case:
And somewhere here, for certain it is said,
There's a Blacks' grave-ground -- Oh, this silly head!
Besides, Peg may forget to bed the sow,
Big Boss, that is so near her pigging now;
Nor can she by herself, with all her care,
Secure the stack from that downdacious mare;
Or pen those rascal calves up from the kine --
I must regain the road! -- Oh, this thick head o' mine!"
Thus grimly summarising his distress,
On, dogg'd and desperate, he at random presses.
Ah! Will, dame Fortune owes thee some shrewd spite!
Thy blazing hearth shall know thee not to night!
In vain thy Peg now watches for her Will
To loom in sight upon the 'customed hill,
Saying the while, with a most wifely frown,
"He's boozing somewhere -- but I'll comb him down!"
And just as vainly dost thou onward plod,
Dismally cooeying almost every rod,
And wishing, 'tween whiles, thou hadst there with thee.
Good neigbor Wilson -- just for company!
But honest Wilson would himself, no doubt,
Be rather in on such a night thanout,
Though with his crony, Will -- and through a drinking-bout.
Now thickest glooms blank every forest path,
And like a large Cyclopic eye in wrath,
One only star glares redly down, as seen
Up through a rent in heaven's dun cloudy screen:
Which gap slow crossing, like a dim-drawn streak,
The owl pours forward his funeral shriek.*
Sounds of strange waters through the turmoil vast
Of the widedark woods, dash over in the blast;
Or the lank dingo's long and weary cry
Comes wildly wailing from some covert nigh.

note.p:
* The bird here meant is, I think, a sort of night hawk,
and not an owl. At all events, at a place in the interior where
I was once residing, the screeches of a supposed screech-owl, used
to be frequently heard in a particular part of the adjacent forest, and
being one night out opossum shooting in that direction, I fired at a
large bird in the air and brought it down. It turned out to be a
species of hawk, of a greyish color generally, but speckled
on the breast and neck with brown; and from that night
forward the aforesaid screeches ceased to be heard anywhere there-
about -- at least during the whole time, a period of several months,
which I afterwards remained in the neighbourhood. But what do
naturalists yet know about out Australian night birds? Next
to nothing. Besides the so called screech-owl, there is a night-bird
that cooeys, like a blackfellow, and another that cries ha hah! as
if in derision; one that shouts go go! and another that makes
shrill word-like exclamations, such as might be mistaken, when at

lg.l: Startlingly near, and phantom-like to see,
The sharp-voiced bidawong streams from tree to tree.
Rocked high in some old gum, the opossum sways,
A nest-like lump , amid the hanging sprays,
Or craning outward through the gusty dark,
Croons to his mate there in the ironbark.
Or the spare curlews that from all points meet
In nightly gatherings fugitive and fleet --
That half ubiquitous appear to be,
Now near, now distant, interthrongingly --
Send suddenly upward in the hollow gale
Cries dismal, -- drear as those of Spectres pale
That round some scene of wholesale murder wail!
Or the wild cat, with breath-suspending rush,
Whisks, imp-like, from some goblin-featured bush!
Or startled kangaroos, dark-bounding high,
String like a troop of shadowy devils by!
Ah, Will! such hour may well thy spirit grieve --

lg.l: Worn out at last, he settles down, -- and Sleep
There finds him, coiled beside that bleaching heap
Of leaves and sprays, whose sear accessions fast
Patter about him, dropping from the blast,
While laden with its over-rushing might,

Wide sway the huge dark trees above the unconscious
wight.
But now, when negress Night her denser shades
Had westward drawn, and grey had grown the glades,
Stung into partial consciousness 'twould seem
By the increasing cold, he dreams a dream.
A banished man, 'neath Polar skies he fares,
On all hands menaced by dread herds of bears!
Enormous fellows! shaggy, icy, -grim
With hunger, and all bent on tasting him!
Begins the onslaught! horrible his plightaffright
Great his despair! yet he maintains the fight!
But just as in the strife an arm is lost,
(That luckless arm least sheltered from the frost)
Sweating and wild, he wakes: -- relieved, 'tis true,
Yet in a strait that ferrits him anew.
So sitting up, he first his face, long drawn,
Rubs hard, then looks, and hails the wished-for dawn:

l.add: From whence no doubt the dream suggestion came
That worked about him this wild Queen-Mab game!)

lg.l: Next scans the unknown scene with joylessrueful eyes,
And folds his arms, and shakes his head, and sighs.
When hark! distinctly although far away,
He hears some watch-dog's thrice repeated bay --
Starts from his huddled posture at a bound,
And briskly pushes for the grateful sound.
Nor long his search: for now some morning star
Wheels from the eastern steeps her shining car,
In whose so pallid but effectual sheen
A rude Lodge, dim and picture-like, is seen,
There where a clearing from yon hill spreads out,
With stumps all dotted, nor yet fenced about.
Thither he hastens, and is welcomed there,
Consoled and fed with hospitable care,
And when the sun shall crown the wintry day,
His host can set him on his homeward way.
O'er the hunch of a mountain piled to the sky,
Through a cloud-gate of burning gold,
The sun looks, like a great red eye,
Sheer down on the smoking Fold:
While the stirring sheep forth staring keep,
Their Shepherd to behold.
Out of his well-slabbed Lodge thereby,
Singing a merry rhyme
He comes -- for the tide of his heart runs high
For joy in the bracing prime;
And with him a Lad comes ready and glad --
His help in the lambing time.*

And often through the live-long day
The mountain nooks among,
The echoes hid in the caverns grey
With tangled brakes o'erhung,
Shall merrily mock from rock to rock
The peal of his mellow tongue.
Hark! 'tis the grate of the Fold's lath-gate
Thrown wide with a swinging shock;
And then one huddling countless bleat
From the fast out pouring Flock,
Spreads onward, with a spreading beat
Of many pattering tiny feet:
Likest of all things to the fall
Of rain upon a rock.

lg.l: And tinkle, tinkle, as they go,
The wedder-bell is heard;
Tinkle, tinkle, sweet and low,
Like the voice of the dingle-bird,*
By which, where hidden waters flow,
The crag-pent air is stirred.
And merrily still their dams before
As pastureward they go,
The lambs crowd out, to scamper o'er
Some known bank to and fro,
Which then doth seem as they over it stream
A drifting bank of snow.**

lg.l: And ever as some one will start
A-head with a wilder joy,
Yet gladlier skips the old Shepherd's heart,
Grown old in such employ --
And to the sound of their swarming feet
Showering along like falling sleet,
As a gleeful bird might its pinions beat,
So claps his hands the Boy.
But why doth a swift pang now wring
His eager face -- to see

div.p:
Merino types, they were so -- the major part of them having a snowy
fleece or floss upon the extremity of the staple, which did not fall away
from it until they were several weeks old. And it is also worthy of remark
perhaps, that the wool of the lambs having this fleece or floss upon
them, was finer and less harsh than the wool of those
that were then born without it: notwithstanding that it
very evidently resulted from a strain of the coarse Cape
