lg.l: One lamb in the midst of that glad crowd bring
Less mirth than there in its midst should be --
A slender and broken spirited thing
Snatching a fearful glee?
And lo, its eye, abashed and meek,
Sends oft a furtive glance
The presence of the Boy to seek,
As he views it there askance:
Then, strange to say, amid its play
It cowers, and turns about,
And slinks at once to the Flock away
From the thick of that merry rout.
What can there be in that Urchin's mood
To cloud that lambkin's fate?
"The Boy is brave at heart and good,
Though given at times to hate,
And somewhat will-wild from the rude
Inbreathings of the lonesome wood:"
So saith his ancient Mate.
And sooth, there is a forest cast
About his meagre face,
As into it the moods had passed
Of many a lonely place,
And, settling there, infixed the air
Of some half Indian race.
And he is paler than a Lad
So free of limb should be,
And in his eye there lurks some sad
And singular mystery:
And that you Lamb he worketh wrong
Whose look, even, scares it from the throng,
Is pianfully plain to see.
Alas! his mortal hate hath curst
A Creature that he loved at first --
Loved in a gentle sort:
Day by day this passion grew
To see it in its sport,

l.add: And

lg.l: And many a fond thing would he do
Its mute regard to court.
And ever his keen love to feed,
When forward the old Man should speed
To head the Flock -- alone
Leaving him there behind, to keep
The lambs all strown about in sleep --
In snowy patches strown,
On this particular one he'd creep,
And sometimes sieze it at a leap,
And sometimes chase it down.
And when the little trembler so
Was taken, he would place
Its foremost feet his chin below
And gaze into its face:
But only fear was living there --
Not what he yearned to trace.
Oh! had it been a thing with speech
Tow'rds which his love did glow,
Some sympathy within their reach
Sweet words had given to flow;
And through the might of his strange delight
To have wakened a kindred mood,
Had kept its fountain pure and bright,
And welling forth for good.
But in the turned and timid face
He loved so well, to find
Of love and jpy no answering trace,
While fear had there a constant place,
So shocked at length his mind
And shamed his heart, -- that in his grief
He turned to hatred for relief!
Of so extreme a kind
Is the bitter smart of a young loneheart
Whose love is cast behind.
"Wild wretch!" he cried: "Why this dismay --
This struggling to be free?

l.add: Can

lg.l: Can nothing that I do or say
Avail to win from thee
Or trust or fellowship? -- Away!
And now beware of me"
And daily then this hatred grew,
Till it erelong became
A load his very soul did rue:
And the mystery of the same,
After it still, like a scorpian, drew
A burning sting of shame.
A hateful shame! And then he'd take
The lambkin as before,
But not, as thenonce, the love to slake
That glowed in his life's red core;
But aye to beat and evil entreat
The Creature more and more.
At last a murderous intent
Did fasten upon his will,
And keep him pondering as he went
How he might safely Kill
The hated little Innocent,
And yet its blood not spill!
For by the Lodge-fire, he of Cain
Had erewhile heard with dread,
And how the blood of Abel slain
Although in secret shed,
Did cry to God from the conscious sod,
Where it lay in a pool so red!
And thus he feared to shed its blood,
Though fully bent to slay:
And wrung by this same murderous mood
Was he upon that day,
Whereon we saw the Flock outrun
At the red reprise of the sun,
And all the lambs in play.
And outward still as the Flock did hie
Upon that morning bright,
A rushy plat, as he followed by,
Did take the Urchin's evil eye --
"Here, crouching out of sight,
As the sheep home in the evening gloom,
I'll wreak (thought he) my spite!
Tied by the neck in the rushes here,
And left deserted, surely Fear
Will kill it in the night!"
The Mom hath died in its mountain pride,
And yet the Flock feeds out --
Till his sun-robe, flaming at noon world-wide,
Old Time, for haste, hath half cast aside,
Trending west with a shadowy stride --
And then 'tis fetched about,

l.add: And

lg.l: And taught to keep with a well-spread sweep
Upon the homeward route.
And now the golden Eventide
Is glowing in the west --
Glowing like a Summer bride
Upon old Winter's breast!
Oh! how can Hate in all the wide
And lovely world, thus beautified,
Dare harbour unconfest --
Nor casting off its hellish scroff
Transform to a Spirit blest?
So feels even that rude-nurtured child
If his heart aright I read --
And yet as though the woody wild
The fleecy breeders feed
Wide-whitening homeward -- should they pass
Near yonder nook, even there, alas!
Will he do a hateful deed!
And the ground is moist, and the spear grass high,
And the herbage greenest there,
And thither still, as the rest graze by,
The elder dams repair,
And after each one her lamb doth run
To frisk in so fresh a lair.
And thither too, at their pattering heels,
His hate the Boy hath brought:
And now on the doomed Lamb he steals --
He pounces -- and 'tis caught!
Then stooping, he his form conceals,
And ponders, pale with thought.
But suddenly a darksome glee
Glooms outward from his mind,
And with a fierce impatience he
Around its neck doth bind
And knot the rushes, so as there
What time the Flock shall onward fare,
To leave it tied behind!
And the dark like a pall down over all
Is dusking through the air;
And only its own little self so white
To behold in the boundless gloom of night,
How shall it madden with affright
In that so lonesome lair?
That terrible Boy, in his cruel joy,
Ah! can he leave it there?
The dams have left it every one,
At first forth stringing slow --
But now far on the whole have run,
As faster the head sheep go:
That cruel Lad, however bad,
Ah! can he leave it so?
He can! he will! and homeward still
He driveth on and on:
And now his ancient Mate before
Their halting charge is gone,

l.add: The

lg.l: The dams into the Fold to score --
And thereof lacking none,
Come Lad, saith he, to our ease will we,
For a good day's work is done.
But from the settling Flock, ere long,
Did he begin to mind,
How oft one strong bleat -- sorrow-strong,
Went out in the hollow wind:
And shaking his head, the old Man said
We have left a lamb behind.
And then the the wrong the Boy had done
Did sorely against him plead!
Darkly he supped apart, to shun
The thoughtful Shepherd's heed:
For at each long bleat, the block-raised slab
He sate on, jarred, as it fain would blab
The tale of his wicked deed.
All through the forewatch of the night
That mournful Mother's wail,
Did thus reproach his cruel spite
Till in the dying gale,
Out desolately far, he thought
Her Lamb's faint voice he also caught,
And his conscience then like a Fury wrought,
And his wilful heart did quail.
And so, all in the dead midnight
Unto himself he said,
I'll fatch it home! -- His heart grew bright,
For Mercy is ever a spirit of light,
And he leaped from his thorny bed --
But to stand aghast as if stricken fast
Into cold stone with dread!

l.add: For

lg.l: For sees he not in the lightless room
The Victim of his spite!
But never might gleam in the solid gloom
A living Lamb so white!
And there is the power of some terrible doom
In the glow of its eyes so bright!
Breathless, pulseless, long he stared!
Long, ghostly stiff, he stood!
When from the hearth on a sudden flared
From the covered and smouldering wood,
A wild flash of light on that Spectre so white --
And lo, from its side ran blood!
While in the dark, out o'er the roof,
Was heard a low wild moan,
As of a Spirit there aloof
In misery and alone:
A hollow sound, that, wasting, went
Away into the firmament:
And the Boy shut fast his eyes at last,
And heaved a fearful groan.
Then blindly staggering back to bed,
On the old Man loud he cried;
Who, starting from his calm sleep, sped
In wonder to his side,
And there learned all as it did befall,
And where the Lamb was tied.
Straightway his clothes he hurried on,
And hurried at once away,
That good old Man: and as alone
The quietly Urchin lay,
An age of fear, it seemed, had fled
In darkness by, ere the Shepherd's tread
Was heard again, a loudening plain
Upon the homeward way.
And then, as past the Fold in sight
He came, thus spake the ancient Wight:
Alas, for thee, poor dam!
Some evil Creature of the night
Hath slain thy pretty Lamb!
All torn I found it where 'twas tied --
Oh,God! the listening Boy out cried,
The murderer that I am!
Yes, thou done a fearful deed,
The old Man made reply;
And to the Lord of all hast need
With a contrite heart to cry,
Till sorrow true and penance due
Win pardon from on high.
Yet lie not moaning there, my son,
But up, and get thee drest,
And rouse the Flock with the rousing sun,
For of all ways, the best
To pay for the wrong thou'st done to one,
Is justice to the rest.
But he had sickened -- and his bed
Kept many a day and night:
And oft -- See there again! he said,
It cometh, ghostly white!
There in the gloomdepth of the darkeninglighter room,
Which is piercedPiercing the longnight's long settled gloom with the glow ofits eyes so bright!
Thus lay he -- till his heart did break
Into a wondrous prayer,
That God the Father of all would take
Sweet pity upon him for sorrow's sake,
Thus lowly lying there!
Nor let the wrong that he had done,
Being tempted of the Evil One,
Some deadlier fruit yet bear!
And when he had prayed, he felt, he said,
Some mystic Presence bright
Burn downward, as from heaven, on spread
And healing wings of light,

l.add: And

lg.l: And turn to a holy hope the dread
That came with the darksome night!
And thereupon, all suddenly
He rose, from sickness freed,
And shouted -- "Now I know for me
That Mercy herself shall plead,
Till sorrow true and penance due
Annul my sinful deed!"
And first this burthen did he lay
Upon himself that night:
Whenever a Lamb should chance to stray,
Chance often as it might,
He'd neither rest nor quit the quest
Until the morrow's light.
Still sometimes o'er his conscious ear
Long after there would come,
A long bleat, sorrowful and drear,
Announcing through the gloom
That Spectre Lamb so thoroughly white
And wondrous to behold.
As erst it met his fated sight,
And reproached his soul with its eyes so bright
In the Lodge at the old Sheep-fold.
And then with a most contrite heart
And fervent would he pray,
To see the Phantom at once dispart,
Shot through with a golden ray,
As shred into air is a mist wreath rare
By the first long beam of day.
Thus came, thus vanished, to the last,
The Spetre of this wild rhyme:
But ever as it were wasting fast,
Paler and fainter it came and past
At each recurring time,
Till sorrow true and penance due
Had cleansed him of his crime.

div.head:
XThe Rose of Abana:
(An Oriental Eclogue).

lg.l: How beautiful was she whom men once called
The Rose of Abana! my early youth's
Enchantment, and my manhood's promised bride!
When my full strength was like a lion's, -- roused
Forth from his lair, being menaced from without;
My fleetness like a roe's, -- when on the hills
In all the wild exultancy of flight,
Seen bounding. But my weary head is now,
Like Winter, white and bleak -- and where the while
Is rosy Myrza? where my youth's delight?
The promised glory of my manhood -- where?
Hark! as if Nature for her lost child yet
Were mourning through the wide world unconsoled,
An Echo from the mountain with a far
And shuddering intonation, answers Where?
Since in the triumph of the Harvest Home
Amongst the virgins I beheld her last,
Glow, dancing, -- like a peerless star amid
The sparkling throngs of heaven, -- how many years
Have joined their shadowy portions to the Past,
And all that weary time have I been thus
In heart alone! For in her Father's house
Myrza died early. Into the cruel grave
In all her maiden happiness she fell.
To-day I called her mine: To-morrow came,
And who might then dispute her with the dark
And clammy Grave's white worm? Down with her went
All my life's richness, like a sunset, drawn
For ever down into the dark of time!
Oh! what a vacuum of the world it made --
A drear dull-aching emptiness -- to know
That never her glad-coming step again
Might call out rapture from my listening heart,
Even as an Echo from her silent cell,
In happy wonder, with a wild throb, leaps;
To meetMeeting the life-stir that comes beating up
Out of green pastures , wakened by the Morn;
Or make my soul, through its serenest depths,
To shudder with a pleasure so extreme
That it resembled pain. Yet through long years
Have worn me with their cold and constant drip
Of joyless day on day, from youth to age,
Her memory lieth warm upon my brain,
Her form is pictured on my eyelids yet
In all its wondrous beauty: I have but
To close them, to behold it in the blank
That then were else around me. In the fresh
And sweet-voiced Spring she died -- and never more
Came Spring to me! Its freshness with her bloom.
Had faded, and its once-glad melody marked
Only the loss of her harmonious breath.
Like clusters of the vine, when in the light
They gleam with ripeness, in bright masses hung
The curled glories of her graceful head:
While, under silk-smooth brows, her azure eyes
Yearned deep as the blue dome of heaven, unfilmed
Even with a summer cloud; -- serenely blue,
Yet glowing , like moist violets, when the sun
First steppeth out from some let eastern steep --
Out into space, and while the globy dews,
The unbought jewels of the morning, yet flame
Flame inIn all their fleeting beauty. Like two gardens
Of roses and lilies mingled were her cheeks --
Two gardens over against each other blooming
Upon the slope sides of a sunny hill,
When Summer flushes with her earliest fruits,
And mated wild birds warble. And most like
A singing bird of price within a cage
Of ivory, curtained with a crimson blind,
To hide it, when 'twas meet, from eyes prophane,
Her well-taught tongue discoursed delectable melody
In the sweet prison of her gracious mouth.
Nor sweeter than her breath itself was, are
The fragrant pantings of a wakening breeze,
Which after soft and shiny showers have wept
With a bright passing grief, the flowery death
And burial of the love-remembered Spring,
Out of some bowery maze comes like her soul
Effusing from the earth. Her shapely neck
Was as a shaft of polished alabaster
Having a spirit of warm life within --
As smooth-wrought milky marble, with a quick
Rich flow of blood in its blue-branching viens.
Her gentle breasts, secretively beneath
Their silken robe, were like a downy pair
Of nestling turtle doves, -- there, in their soft
And innocent concealment breathing both
So warmly. And her ever agile motion
Was as the pacing of a glad gazelle --
One of a year old that hath never looked
From out the secret places of the hills
Upon the hunter's form; and thence hath nought
In all its happy attitudes to hint
Infirmity of impulse or of will --
Nothing betokening a doubt-shadowed life,
Or conscious lapse of peace.
Thus richly meet
And beautifully blooming to the eye,
Was Myrza! And no guile, no evil, lurked
Like a bowered serpent hid in flowers, beneath
Those visible graces: for her young desires
Were utterly innocent, -- like a troop of lambs,
When briskly gathered in a snowy knot
Out of the mother flock, it streameth then
Along the green bank of some pleasant brook,
That spends in shady Abana its cool
And murmurous life. -- But what indeed availed
Her innocence, her tenderness, and all
Her wondrous beauty? In her Father's house
Early she died. Into the cruel grave
Even in her maiden happiness she fell!
And I, her chosen one, with time and grief
Thus bleached and broken, -- am not I the slave
Of tasking strangers in an alien land.
In the deep sacred solitude of night
A solemn Vision, like a sudden cloud,
Shadowed my soul. Loved voices and far tones
Flowed as if breathing out of the dead Past,
Over my heart, -- till, with a dim dread joy,
I felt a sweet in the near gloom beside my bed,
Stilly and tall: -- and when I thither looked,
'Twas Myrza! the beloved of my youth,
Even as in her lifetime she had stood
Beside me oft in Abana; -- the same!
Save that her sweet face now looked wildly wan,
And that her dove-like eyes, with moveless lids,
Shone fixed and gleamy, as still waters shine
Under their palmy fringes. Forth I stretched
My arms -- but empty on my yearning breast
Together fell they, folded! and again
The wary weight of many lonesome years
Rolled whelming, like a monstrous wave of pain,
Back on my heart. The white and solemn light
Of the cold midnight Moon came slanting through
The lattice from a lurid cloud's lit verge;
The mixing murmurs of the wind grew loud
Amongst the sycamores beyond the brook,
Whose voice rose sobbing, stronglier it seemed,
Under that leafy turmoil; while through all,
A sudden bleating from the hill-side fold
Poured troublous down; and at the gate my dog
Howled wildly, -- howled as if, even over him,
As over me, the Spirit of the Past,
While it went sorrowing through the hollow dark,
Had swept too, wail-like, -- leaving, when it sunk

l.add: Into some doom-depth infinitely out,

lg.l: A sole sad sense of utter loss behind.
Let me gaze westward, where she keeps afar
The sabbath silence of her early grave!
Let me gaze westward, where that sacred spot,
In the warm Springtime , takes the morning's glance,
And shones all jewelled with the tears of night,
Or, like an emerald, in the sunset glows.
One Summer morn, out of the sea waves wild
A speck-like cloud, the season's fatal child,
Came gladly glidingsoftly floating up the broad blueboundless sky,
And o'er the sun-parched hills all brown and dry.
Onward she glided, through the azure air
Borne by its motion without toil or care;
When looking down in her ethereal joy
She marked Earth's moilers at their hard employ:
And oh, (she cried) that by some act of grace
'Twere mine to succor yon load-wearied race,
To give the hungry food, the thirsty drink --
The thought of good is very sweet to think.
The day advanced -- and the Cloud greater grew,
And greater still; and her desire to do
Some charity to mankind had, more and more
As the long arid Summer day on wore,
Greatened and warmed within her fleecy breast
Like a dove fledging in its downy nest.
The heat waxed fiercer, until all the land
Glared in the sun's rays like a mighty brand.
Ill could Earth's children their long toil enduresons endure their toilsome state
Though still they toiledlabored, for they were very poortheir need was great.
And many a look, with many a sigh, they sped
Tow'rds yonthat fair Cloud; -- beseeching looks, that said
We famish for thy help! For pity's sake,
Oh, break thou! in a showery blessing break!
I feel, and I would help you! said the Cloud,
And tow'rds the Earth her bounteous being bowed.
But then rememb'ring a tradition she
Had, while a child, learned from her native sea,
That when a Cloud adventures from the skies
Too near the altars of the hills -- it dies!
Awhile she wavered, and was blown about,
Hither and thither, by the winds of doubt.
But in the midst of Heaven at length all still
She stood, and said within herself, I will!
Yea, in the glad strength of devotion, I
Will help you, though, in helping you, I die.
Filled with this thought's divinity, the Cloud
Grew world-like vast, as earthward more she bowed!
Oh, never erewhile had she dreamtguessed her state
So great might be -- great!
O'er the parched fields in her angelic love,
She spread her wings out like a brooding dove:
Till, as her purpose deepened, drawing near,
So god-like terrible did her facefront appear,
That men and beasts all trembled at the view,
And the woods bowed, -- through well all creatures knew
That near in her, to every kind the same,
A great predestined Benefactor came.
Yea, I will help you! said the Cloud again:
Receive me -- lo, I die for you -- in rain!
Suddenly flashed then through her full-grown form
The glory of her will -- the agony and the storm
Of that contentious with Life's self- to-- dire -- dread of Death, whose mortal threat

lg.l: Flashed, seething out of rents amid her heaps
*Of lowering gloom, and thence with arrowy leaps
Hissed jagging downward, till a sheety glare
Illumined all the illimtable air!
The thunder followed, a tremendous sound
Loud doubling and reverbaerating round,
Till one wide rumbling intonation rolled

note.l: Of Life's dire dread of Death, whose &c

lg.l: Through all the shuddering mountains manifold!
Through all the shuddering mountains manifold!
Strong was her will, but stronger yet the power
Of love that now dissolved her in a shower,
Dropping in blessings, to impregn the earth
With health and plenty at one booming birth.
She bled in rain, bled unto death, but died
Only to higher being -- Good beatified!
Far as the rain extended o'er the Land
A spledndid bow the freshened prospect spann'd,
As the last greeting of the spirit pure
Of Love self-sacrificed, and thence made sure,
Because in record on the Eternal writ
In faith and hope, and therefore one with it:
One in duration, and in glory one,
With all that God-ward out of Time hath gone.
--The rainbow vanished, but the blessing craved
Long rested on the land the Cloud had saved.
Full in the centre of a region named
The Land of Vain Display, a mansion stands,
Built by debauched artificers of old
For prodigal Pleasure in her palmiest days,
The foundress vain of a vain-glorious race,
Profuse though needy, arrogant though light
And loose of life, and always in their day
As greedy of prominence as void of worth.
A structure large, and splendid to the eye,
Pillared and porched, but meretricious more
Than graceful in its style, -- with gilded domes,
And glittering pinnacles that flash aloft
Like giant lances pointed at the sky,
And carven windows in their ribbed rows blazing
O'er the long colonades. A Mansion large
And solid in its seeming still it stands;
But inwardly impaired and worn is now
The whole huge structure; in its basement most --
Knawed through with damps and crumbling unrenewed.
That is the House of Riot: the set place
Of much vain speech and simulated mirth,
(For true Mirth seldom quits her sylvan lodge)
And fleshly feasting. From its unblest door
Simplicity, and Strength, and red-lipped Health,
And native Cheerfulness, and staunch Resolve,
Wise Care, and Prudence, and domestic Peace,
And Piety who loves with these to dwell,
For ever, as of old, they spurn away:
For as their household duties instead
Have they installed Extravagance, disguisedin the guise
AsOf Bounty, but in truth the slave of self;
And false Refinement, sensually nice
But vulgar and indelicate of soul;
And Infidelity; and the gamester Craft
Dressed in the airs and habit of a sage;
And Atheism, mantled in a gownmuffled in a garb
Fashioned as 'twere the mantle of a a prophet's seer.
Now, ye for whom I sing, -- evenSo peopled is that House! And -- Now, while Thought's
Keen kindled spirit lightens through my brainsoul.
Intent to benefit the young, to thee,
O Wisdom, do I cry, and thee invoke
To aid the voice that I would pour abroad
In a melodious though a warning song!
So pure the inspiring motive, that 'twere well
Couldst thou inflame it, as it peals along,
With lightnings of intelligence, and all
Its monitory tones enforce and swell
With soul-heard[voluble] thunders, such as Spiritslost-souls hear !

l.add: For ever roaming o'er their guilty Past!
Give heed then, ye who would be early wise

lg.l: Be early wise! My weighted linesMy sober numbers, big with thought, shall be
Meet robes for Wisdom in her quuenliest plight --
Yea, though she sat again enthroned as once
With Solomon of old. And know ye not
What even the reprobate, though godless, knows;
That he who in the morning of his life
Good counsel scorns -- indubitably good,
Shall, a grey prodigal, wander forth with Shame,
And vain Remorse, and outcast Poverty,
Under the lengthening shadows that portend
Its sunset, ending in the dark of nightdeath.
Wherefore with reason verily I say,
That froward-hearted youth who shall esteem
The Preacher's words but as the profitless
Roughening the forehead of some sterile hill
Shall thrive not! -- but, a moving pile of rags,
In houseless age shall eat the begger's dole;
Or with stark limbs and aching sinews ply
The 's axe, or bend beneath his yoke;
Or at the mill of never-varying toil,
Even to the dregs of a brute being ,, grind, --
Laboring for others more than for himself.
And though he be the exception, not the less
Shall he be bondsman to Infirmity:
Nay, even though greatness fall within his lot,
Which thing mightmay happen in a graceless age)
Yet shall he, as did Bacon, through a need
Induced by a vain habit of display,
Mush up by his glory with the vilest things,
And be at once a scoundrel and a lord!
Oh, we should honor Wisdom, since through her
The all-contriving One designed and built
This boundless world! Yea, she it was who first
Glanced the sun on his imperial course,
Day's monarch, vested with celestial fire;
Her hand it was that fashioned the round moon
And all the golden stars. Or couldst thou soar
Up to the throne of God, there were she found
In presence, circled with ineffable splendor;
Or to the unfathomable gulfs of Hell
Down couldst thou plunge, behold! there -- even there,
Wisdom would would meet thee, though obscured, as when
The day in its meridian strength is seen
Darkened with storms, that bellow as they roll.

l.add: But lo, the House of Riot! the set place

l.del: Of Riot, the set place of much vain speech,
l.add: Of much vain speech, much [enviousriotous] display,

lg.l: And fleshly feasting, and pretensive mirth.
There congregate the frivolous of soul,
As garrulous parrots gather to the snares
Set on the borders of the ripening maize.
There Frenzy in the name of earnest Ioy
(A Spirit Spirit native but to honest lives),
With wild embarrassed brows, o'erflows the cups,
With purple ruin, blazing inwardly
As it were fiercely conscious of its power,
While loose-eyed Passion in the plight of Love
Inflames his lows and animal fires withal.
And there, too, Gluttony takes his constant round
As seneschal, high heaping every board
With palatable death.
That fatal House!
Shun it all ye in thought yet young, in heart
Unguarded, and all ye of facile wills;
Lest, like its host, ye with like years should cast
To sow the world for an abundant yield
Of pleasure, -- and mistaken, only reap
An overwhelming load of debt instead --
Of debt, distaste, and vanity, and vexation.
Once entered there, -- disastrous is the change
Wrought in thy nature: a swift evil change!
Thy laughter loud, speech boisterous; -- but alas,
Thy reason silent as the tongue of death;
Thine evil passions as the surging flames
That, like red flags, flap over the wild front
Of some wide forest fire, -- sultry and fierce
As legioned demons, jubilant; -- but all
Thy virtues, like the wintry crust that numbs
The living brook till it forgets to flow.
Then 'neath the growing influence of the fierce
And fatal spirit of that evil House,
So recklessly familiar shalt thou grow
With splendid Ruin, as to kneel and kiss
Here kneel Isee me -- ready to impawn at once
The pearls of truth -- the sapphires of my peace --
The rubies of repute; -- yea, all with which
I late adorned my soul, for lures and gauds
And glittering baubles wherewithal to deck
My body, dedicate henceforth to thee.
Into her inmost secret chambers then
Straight shalt thou follow her -- desperately fond:
While lovely Phantoms beckon thee along:
Lovely -- but fleeting as the shapes that crest
A morning cloud: lovely -- but weird, and quick
With mischief, -- bright for evil, like that wild
Mysterious light which nightly glides about
Some shrouded marsh, misleading him who sees
Into the foul ways of a darkling death.
And passionate airs, intense and sweet as those
The enthusiast, when to reason dying, hears
In mountain glens, or wooded vales, or near
Some lone lake crimsoned by the setting sun,
Shall hail thy presence, vapouring all the air
With sweetness -- and awakening raptures sweet
And spirit-elating; -- but delusive all
As are the hopes of unrequited love:
Sweet-sweet; -- but cruel as untimely death.
Then with the histories of royal lust
In her right haqnd displayed, and in her left
A chronicle in which the eminent damned
Are registered as wise, thy yielded heart
Baptise shall she in the lewd mysteries
Of fashionable folly; and at last
Instruct thee, with a devil's zeal, how best
To smother down in thy disnatured soul,
As in a quagmire, the prophetic hope
That once, with wings like the unwearying stock's,
Would rise and soar from the brute Earth away,
Through the Eternal and the Infinite,
To rest at length in Heavenwithin the gates of within those starry gates
That lets the into the central peace of .
--But who is this, that sceptered with a whip,
ThatIn yon loud chariot cometh flaming on,
InWith costliest raiment clad, and tricked with gauds
Of gold and glittering jewelsburnished metal and all be dropt? with gems?
Who so obscure himself as not to know you not
The sun of Fashion, and the worshipped star
Of prodigal pomp and towering excess?
I know not him you mean.of none so styled. But who is this,
With glittering ornaments bedizzened so
That he himself is lost in their display?
Even he, -- that charioteer, is Fashion's sun,
And the presiding star of Revelry!
Is there a haunt for deep carousals famed,
He is dictator there; and where the vain
Hold triumph, in the courts of outward show,
All know him, all admire him, and cry hail!

l.add: Wouldst thou that one with influence so pronounced,

lg.l: Should sid the blest and blessing cause of Charity?
The shoulder-shrugging ribald shall reply
He loves not a cold mistress. Wouldst thou he
Should help prophetic Genius, or assist
Poor Learning, laboring in the mines of Truth
To enrich a thankless world? The miscreant's means
Are all through waste encumbered, or forestalled
Long heretofore. What if his Country's need
Besought her sons to gather like a storm
And seeep Invasion from her sacred coasts,
Or thunder signal condemnation down
On statecraft, and on all internal wrong?
Her need might move him not: for he is one
Whose strength, long since, of soul and body both, long since
Hath been vain gloriously drenched away
In midnight orgies, by the flowing bowl.
Of him, in thine extremity, go seek
Condolence and advice: -- No search so vain!
The veriest frensy shall he froth thee forth.
With the high polish of his boasted wit
Go burnish thou thy studious front: -- Alas!
'Tis but a stale anthology of the jests
That celebrate the stews. His usefulness
Hath passed already; -- fruitless as a stone
Sunk in his sterile yesterdays it lies,
The buried talent that shall yet condemn
His thriftless being with the Lord of Life;
His understanding, with like lumber, rots
Already in Oblivion -- that dim Cave
Whose vague-rent wasteful month stands wide a-gape
Out in the void of unrecorded time.
Then in the House of Riot seek ye not
For pleasure, nor for knowledge from its vain
And gaudy Paracites, ye young ones, lest
A fever of spirit for the first ye catch,
And for the other wed a lasting folly!
Rather seek wisdom in the House of Woe,
And in the rugged ways of Want and Toil,
Where Fortune, though severe, is full of truth;
Or meditate her amid ruined tombs
Charged with thedust of ages, -- dust that once
Was the warm human beauty of the world.
But not for sourness, or to gloom the soul,
In sorrowful places should we seek her most,
And with a solemn heed; but well to know
And weigh the value of our earthly lot;
And be thence be guardful of so much of weal
(In substance solid and in measure just)
As may befall us, and (if so it chance)
Prepared for loss and equal to adversity:
Deferring all things in their final ends
And ultimate peace, and piety, and a sage
And serious power for good, are ever found
In final union in this destiny of Manhis lot, who much

lg.l: Thus far the Preacher warmeth: and although
His lot be lowly and his years but few,
Despise ye not his words; for he is one
Who much hath labored in the special fields
Where grey Experiences sows her golden grain;
Reapt there for knowledge with a strenuous care,
And threshed and ground for excellence of speech.
For Thought espoused him in his infancy:
And when a child, consorted with his mates
In the old wood, or by the stream thatwhere the Hawksbury past
Its ready marge went simmeringgoes displaying, he hath looked
Upon the careless and unguarded flowers
With eyes that felt, through their presageful heed,
The coming hurricane, his pregnant words
Have yielded fruit even to druid Eld
Who chanced to hear them as he passed along.

div.head: Final copyThe Dream by the Fountain.

lg.l: Thought-weary and sad, I lay down by a Fountain
At the head of a white-cedar shaded ravine,
And the breeze that fell over the high-glooming mountain
Sang a lullaby low as I gazed o'er the Scene.
Long I'd reclined not till slumber came o'er me,
Grateful as balm to a suffering child:
When a lofty-souled Maiden seemed standing before me
With a lyre in her hand -- O so sounding and wild!
Bright was her brow, not the morning's brow brighter,
But her eyes were two midnights of passionate thought;
Light was her motion, a breeze's not lighter,
And her locks were like sunshine and shadow inwrought.
Never before did my bosom inherit
Emotion so thrilling, such exquisite awe!
Never such wonder exalted my spirit
Before, as did now, through the Vision I saw.
Robed for the chase like a Nymph of Diana,
Her ivory limbs were half given below, --
Bare, that the pure breath of heaven might fan her,
Bare was her bosom of roseate snow.
Then lifting the lyre, and with every feeling
Sublimed as with love, she awakened the strings:
Bliss followed -- and half into being came stealing
The motion and light of angelical wings.
Divine were the measures! Each voice of the wildwood
Seem'd gathering head in their musical thrills --
The loud joy of streams in their gladstrong mountain childhood,
The shouting of Echoes that look from the hills;
The moaning of trees all at midnight in motion
When the breezes seem lost in the dark, with a rare
And sweet meaning spirit of human devotion
All blendinged and woven together were there!
Ceased then the strain: and as soon as were flowing
Around but the accents that people the wild,
The Lyrist, subdued by her rapture, yet glowing,
Adjusted her mantle, approached me, and smiled:

l.add: Sighed -- for the fire-robe of Thought had enwound thee,
Betoken'ing how much that the happy most dread

lg.l: Smiled with a look like the radiance of morning
When flushing the crystal of heaven's serene,
Blent with that darkness of beauty adorning
The world when the moon firstjust arising is seen.
And repressing it seemed many fonder suggestions,
Calmy she spake; -- I arose to my knees,
Expectantly glad, while to quiet my questions
The wild-warbled words that she uttered were these:
I am the Muse of the evergreen Forest --
I am the Spouse of thy spirit, lone Bard!
Ev'n in the days when thy boyhood thou worest,
Thy pastimes drew on thee my dearest regard.
For I felt thee, -- ev'n then, wildly, wondrously musing
Of glory and grace by old Hawksbury's side,
Scenes that spread recordless round thee suffusing
With the purple of love -- I beheld thee, and sighed.
*Sighed -- for the fire robe of Thought had enwound thee --thy dream did the more but endear thee
It seemed butof the breeze, or a sigh of thine own!
I would sweep then this lyre, gliding viewlessly near thee,
To give thy emotions full measure and tone.

note.l: And whence there should follow, howe'er it renowned thee,
What sorrows of heart, and what labors of head!

lg.l: Since, have I tracked thee through dissolute places
And seen the with sorrow long herd with the vain;
Lured into error by false-smiling faces --
Chained by dull Fashion though scorning her chain.
Then would I prompt in the still hour of dreaming
Some thought of thy beautiful Country again;
Of her yet to be famed streams through dark woods far gleaming --
Of her bold shores that throb to the beat of the main.
Till at length I beheld the arise in devotion,
To shake from thy heart the vile bondage it bore,
And my joy gloried out like a morning-lit ocean,
When thy footfall was heard in the mountains once more!
Listen, rejoined one; I promise thee glory
Such as shall rise like the daystar apart,
To brighten the source of Australia's broad story,
But for this thou must give to the future thy heart.
Be then the Bard of thy Country! O rather
Should such be thy choice than a monarchy wide!
Lo, 'tis the land of thy the grave of thy father!
'Tis the cradle of Liberty! -- Think, and decide.
Well hast thou chosen.' She ceased. Unreplying,
I gazed, mute with love, on her soul-moulded charms:
Deeper they glowed, her lips trembled, -- and sighing
She rushed to my heart, and dissolved in my arms!
Thus seemed she to pass -- and yet something remaining,
Like a separate Soul in my soul seemed to be --
An aching delight -- an extension, that paining
My spirit, yet made it more strengthy and free.
She passed -- but to leave in my brain a reflexion,
A fore-visioned blaze of perpetual sway;
While tones that seem gushings of mystic affection
Flow through me by night and around me by nightday.
And since, or in cities or solitudes dreary,
Upon the lone hill or more lonely sea sand,
*ThoughNo matter how many that blame, few that praise, be anear me,
I feel like a monarch of song in the Land.

note.l: Now matter how few in my wanderings cheer me
I know that tis mine need the Prophets to stand.

div.p:
It has been pointed out to me, that there is some resemblance between
the manner of this phase of the Vision and that of a similar one in Shelley's Alastor.
But whatever likeness there may have chanced to be between them, my draught cannot
possibly be any copy of his, for the simple but sufficient reason, that up to the time of conceiving
it, and for long after, though I may have heard of Shelley as a writer, I had never read
a line of his writings. My acquaintance with these began as late as in 1842 or 43 --
namely, on the occasion of Mr. Henry Parkes sending me as a present, far into the interior,
a copy of Mrs. Shelley's edition of , in six volumes.

lg.l: High 'mid the shelves of a grey Cliff, that yet
Hangeth in bluffs enormously above,
In a benched cleft, as in the mouldered chair
Of greybeard Time himself, I sit alone,
And gaze with a keen wondering happiness
Out o'er the Sea. Immensely rolling forth,
See how it stretches to the circling bend
That verges Heaven: -- a vast luminous plain
Of waters, changeful as a lover's dream!
Into great spaces mapped by light and shade
In constant interchange, or under clouds
The billows darken, or they simmer bright
In sunny scopes of measureless expanse!
'Tis Ocean dreamless of a stormy hour,
Calm, or but gently heaving; -- yet, O God!
What a blind fate-like mightiness lies coiled
In slumber, under that wide-shining face!
While o'er the watery gleam, -- there, where its edge
Banks the dim vacancy, the topmost sails
Of some tall Ship whose hull is yet unseen,
Hang, as if clinging to a cloud that still
Comes rising with them from the void beyond,
And bellying over, -- like a heavenly net
Drawn slowly upward by ethereal hands.
And if I look aloft, how deep the sky
That arches Ocean! -- depper far, it seems,
Than elsewhere. See how delicately rare
Are those sky colors that keep flickering up
From the remote horizon! Beautiful
Those lucid traceries of woven cloud
That float about the sun; and lustrous too
Are the white masses overheard, that move
And gather inland towa'rds the verdant hills.
Withdrawing now the eye from heaven, behold
The Coast, how wonderful! Proportions strange,
And unimaginable forms, more quaint,
More wild and wayward than were ever dreamt
By a mad architect, keep crowding out
As runs the eye along it. Semblances
Of pyramidic structures vague and rent,
Hunch ledging stairwise from the general range;
Or dark time-wasted columns, leaning out
Under the bluffs, and in their seeming such
As old Assyrian trowels might have reared,
Support fantastic arches. Rugged domes,
And minarets in ruin, freak the sides
Of chasms spann'd by crude and haggard bridges;
Or overhanging Cliffs like this whose shelf
Sustains me, rest on buttresses of more
Than Babylonian vastness; -- while below,
Against their bases everlastingly
Beats the white wrath of the relentless surge.
Yet even amid these rugged forms the warm
And gentle ministry of Spring hath wrought
Its work of love. Most sparingly indeed,
But thence most gratefully, a nameless shrub
With flame-bright blossom, tufts each guttered ledge
That holds a scanty soil; and rarer still,
Green runners from some sheltering crevice throw
Their tendrils o'er the shelves, and trailing thence
Touch the stern faces of the rocks with beauty.
Nor wants the scene its meet inhabitants.
Below the porpoise breaches, and the crab
Waits for his prey amid the wave-washed stones
That glisten to the sun, -- gleaming himself
Whene'er he moves, as if his wetted shell
Were breaking into flame; or more remote,
Out in the watery spaces may be seen
Some solitary diver's shining back.
Sea-gulls go clanging by, and overhead
Sits the white-breasted hawk, with many a sleek
And silver pinioned wanderer in the winds
That furrow the great visage of the Deep,
And who, in conjugal convention met,
Hoard here their mottled eggs and rear their young
Amongst the jags and fissures of the Cliffs.
How nourishing is Nature to the soul
That loves her well! not only as she acts
In instant contact with its quickened powers,
But as she tempers all its aftermoods
Through oldest memories and remotest tokens.
And hence, when thus beloved, not only here
By the great Sea, or amid forests wild,
Or pastures luminous with lakes, is she
A general luminous with lakes, is she
Whatever testifies of her is good,
However common; fresh, however known.
Dead city walls may pen us in, but still
Her influence seeks, to find us, -- even there,
Through many a simple means. A vagrant mass
Of sunshine, falling into some void space,
Shall warm us to the heart, and trade awhile,
Though through some sorrowful reminiscence,
With instincts which regenerated thus,
Make us child-happy. A stray gust of mind,
Pent in and wasting up the narrow lanes,
Shall breathe insinuations to our age
Of youth's fresh promise. Even a bird, though caged,
Shall represent past freedom, and its notes
Be spirited with memories that call

Trailing along some backyard wall, shall speak
Love's first green language; and (so cheap is truth)
A vessel of clear water from the well
Be in its homely brightners beautiful.

div.head: Final copyThe Vision of the Rock.

lg.l: I sate upon a lonely peak,
A backwood river's course to view,
And watched the varying shadows freak
Its liquid length of gleaming blue,
Streaked by the crane slow gliding o'er,
Or chequering to the leafy roar
Of woods that 'neath me grew,
Or curdling dark as high o'erhead
The gathering clouds before the sounding breezes fled.
Beyond a broad herd grazed the vale,
Where, 'mid the trees, its Station stood;
Beneath, a housewife with her pail
Plunged dext'rous, smote the booming flood --
Which suddenly from the reedy nook
Aroused the brooding teal, that took
Her flight along the wood,

l.add: And

lg.l: And drew dull murmurs from each grot,
And called the passing hawk to circle o'er the spot.
Straight I bethought how once the scene
Spread in its primeval horror there,
When but some lone bird's weary threne,
Or howlings from the wild dog's lair,
Or rush of startled kangaroo,
As near some steathly Savage drew
With hunger in his air,
Or from the stream some casual sound
Broke the dread slumb'rous calm of Solitude profound.
A change came o'er my thoughts; -- behind
A length of coming time I threw --
Till round me, on that rock reclined,
Its folds prophetic Vision drew;
And purpling, like the morning, gave
Mine eyes of Freedom's births to have
It seemed an ante-view,
As haply in brave promise stole
His Country's purer weal o'er youthful Hampden's soul.
All round me villages upgrew
At once, with orchards clumpt about,
And oft between, tall pine-rows through,
Some mansion's pillared porch looked out,
And thickening up from alleys green,
Where rustic groups in dance were seen,
Came merry laugh and shout,
While from yet choicer shades, the cheer
Of more refined delight broke in rich wavelets near.
And in the gusts that over passed
The stir of neighboring Cities came,
Whose structures, in the distance massed,
DeclaredProclaimed their opulence and fame,
O'er fields of ripening plenty viewed
Or hills with white flocks fleeced, and strewed
With herds that grazed the same,
While on the paven roads between
The frequent chariot flamed with rapid-rolling din.
Now gaining depth, the Vision lay
Around my being like a law,
So that my spirit might not say
But all was real that I saw:
I mark a youth and maiden, prest
By Love's sweet power, elude the rest,
And as they nearer draw,
I list the vow that each imparts
Folded in the sighed spells of harmonising hearts.
But suddenly a grim-faced Sire
Strides like a fatal wraith between!
With that cold whiteness in his ire.
Which in the bad alone is seen!
Alas! this world can never be
A Poet's Eden utterly --
But much what it hath been!
So long as Love's rich heart is red,
And Beauty's eyes are bright, -- so long shall tears be shed!
They pass: and lo, a lonely Boy
With wandering step goes musing by --
Glory is in his air, and joy,
And all the poet in his eye!
And now whilst rare emotions flush
His happy face, as cloud-hues blush
In morning's radiant sky,
He sings -- and to the charmful sound
Troops of angelic Shapes throng into being round.
Be'neath a shadowingsombre cypress tree,
And clad in garbs of kindred gloom,
A mother and her child I see
Both mourning o'er a lowly tomb!
Ah! Life hath ever been a brief
Mixed dream of glory and of grief --
Its earliest -- latest doom!
That heart in which Love's tides first ran
Descends with all its risks to every child of Man!
But turning, see! with locks all grey,
A Form majestic: wisdom true
Illumes his brow -- the power to weigh
All worth, and look all semblance through;
And stately youths of studious mien,
Children of light, are with him seen,
His auditory, -- who
Attend the speaking Sage along
As though scientical manna issued from his tongue.
Listen! -- he tells of patriot deeds,
And lands the happiness they brought;
He blazens Freedom's holy creeds
With all the affluence of thought;
Teaches the truths of Virtue's cause,
And what are Nations' proper laws,
And what blind Milton taught --
That to avert Oppression's rod
And pull wrong Power down, is -- Glory be to God!
And now doth his big utterance throw
A sacred solemnising spell,
O'er scenes which yet no record know,
Round names that now I may not tell!
But there was one -- too long unknown!
Whereat, as with a household tone
Upon the ear it fell,
Each listener's speaking eyes were given
To glisten with a tear and turn awhile to heaven.
Thus night came on: for hours had flown
And yet its hold the Vision kept,
Till lulled by many a dying tone,
I laid me on the rock and slept.
And now the moon hung big between
Two neighbouring summits sheath'd with sheen --
When all with dews bewept,
And roused by a loud-coming gale,
I sought our camp-fire's glow, -- deep in the darkling vale.

div.l: By mimic Fancy, when alone awake
And thence unhindered in her mystic craft,

lg.l: How wonderful are Dreams! Yet, are they but
(As some suppose) the thin disjoining shades
Of facts and feelings long foregone or late,
As gatheredrecomposed, and disposedput in ghostly act
And strange procession, wildly mixed, and yet
So life-like, though thus composite and wild,
By wakeful Fancy, --in her mimic moodwhen alone awake

l.add: And thence unhindered in her mimic craft,

lg.l: TrackingShe tracks the vaguer drifts of wearied Thought,
Itself sunk sleepward? Wonderful no less
Are they though thus be true; and wondrous more
Is she who in the dark, and stripped of sense,
Can claim such sovereignty -- the Queen of Art!
For what a cunning painter is she then,
And sculptor, who, in bodying from the waste
Of things memorial littering life's dim floor,
The forms and features manifold and quaint
That crowd the timeless vistas of a Dream,
Fails never in a stroke, and breathes as well
A spirit of motion into all her work --
The test of deity; -- inspiring too
Her phantom creatures with more eloquent tones
Than ever broke in subtle waves, like light,
Upon a waking ear?
But are they more?
Sure glimpses oft, though vague, of some wide sea
Of mystic being, on whose lonely shore
Things mortal terminate; and where the pent
Impatient Soul , from its sleep-shrouded crib
Slipping sometimes, is wont to roam at large,
Like Crusoe, staring forth; or musing stand
As once the intelligence of Newton stood
Upon the shores of Time, while the great deep
Of Nature, yet untried, around it loomed
Illimitably out.Under heaven'sthe uncommunicable dome, sky
But vain is all
Conjecture: they are Dreams! and wonderful,
However we may rank them in our lore.
And worthy well asome passing thought are thingsstates
Of our interior being, though aberrant,
That with a wand so capable can bring
Back to the faded heart , the rosy flush
And sweetness of a long fled love, or touch
The eyes of an old enmity with tears
Of a yet older friendship; or restore
A world-lost mate, or reunite in joy
The living and the dead! Yet this can Dreams:
And more as wonderful; -- can, when so wills
Their wand's weird wielder, whatsoe'er it be,
Lift up the fallen -- fall'n however low!
Rejuvenate the worn; enrich the poor;
The past imparadise, and enchant the present;
Build in the future higher than the hope
Of Power, when boldest, ever dared to soar;
Annul , as with the sanction of the Infinite,
The prison bars of place, the dens of time
Giving the rigid and dull-clanking chain
Which Force, that grey inequity, hath clenched
About its captive, to relent, -- yea, stretch
Out into Fairy-land; or melt like wax
In that fierce life whichwhose spirit lightens wide
Round Freedom , seated on his mountain throne!
Or witching Memory, where she darkling lies,
Can so accomplish her , that she can make
All brute bulk ocular, andor the great earth itself spread her wings
Over a whole life timeDiaphanous, like a mighty globe of glassHung in the void of timeOverall ages -- as from east to west
Evolve at once the wings of morn, and show
All things beneath them in one world-wide act,
Instant and universal! -- Wonderful!
But not this always are our dreams benign:
Oft are they miscreations -- gloomier worlds
Crowded tempestuosly with Wrongs and Fears
More ghastly than the Actual ever knew;
And rend with racking noises, such as might
If audible ever to a soul awake,
Go thundering only through the wastes of Hell!
So wonderful are Dreams: and I have had known
Many most wild and strange. And once, long since,
As in the death-like mystery of Sleep
My body lay impalled, my soul arose
And journeyed outward in a dream of wonder. --
In the mid hour of a dark night, methought
I roamed the margin of a waveless Lake,
Which, in the knotted forehead of the land
Deep sunken, like a huge CyclopesCyclopean eye,
Lidless, and void of speculation, stared
Glassily up, -- for ever sleepless, -- up
At the wide vault of heaven; and that I had
Also a vague and mystic consciousness
That over against me, on the farther shore,
Which yet I might not see, there stood a Tower
Such as we read o in some old romance.
The darkness darkened, until overhead
Solid black the starless heaven domed,
And earth was one wide blot -- where, as I looked,
Suddenly lamping through the hollow dark
A Light swing blazing from the unseen Tower,
(Unseen, though prophesied in imagination)
And brought at once its rounded structure forth
Out of the mighty gloom, wherein, till then,
So shut it seemed as one in substance with it.
And when the Light had steadied, hanging there
Against the grim front of the night-backed Tower,
Suspended as by magic, I might see
In the wide Lake whose whole disc now between
Glimmered though dubiously, the falling stream
Of its wild radiance, columnar and vast,
Reach quivering, -- down, like a great shaft of fire,
Through the lit waters.
Long in stedfast wonder
It held me gazing, - till I thence could feel
A strange and thrillingly attractive power
In gradual operation; and ere long,
My bodily weight seemed witched away, and up
mounted, poised within the passive air;
Then glode ascendingly sheer o'er the Lake,
Which, far below, as tow'rds the wondrous light
The attraction drew me, I beheld illumed
Even to its sullen depths with shifting beams,
That tangled Tower-ward into one broad path
Of multifarious splendor, -- one red blaze,
Yet various, wildly interwrithing quick,
As every molecule of the watery mass
Had an organic life, and played a part
Restlessly proper to its wayward self,
Though tending all into one glow of bright
Disunion in bright union.
On I slid:
Nor knew I why -- but my amaze wore off
As thus I glode over the Lake, and still
Approached the Tower and that so wondrous light!
And soon, instead, a many-branching warmth,
Even like the spirit of new love, began
To tingle in my being: and with this
So sweet conception, -- lo, a beateous change!
Within a circular balcony, whose roof
Was fluted silver, lightly propt on four
Pencil-like shafts of jet, whosethe polished [ruleslines]
Of which Descending to an ivory balustraderail,
Glistened in contrast with a covert gleam;
And which, high up the Tower, emporched a huge
And brazen dore, -- behold, a Lady, all
Of light immaculate -- yea, face and form
All of a Hesper radiancy composed,
And lovelier than lustrous, stood alone,
Yet, as it seemed, expectant; for as still
She witched me tow'rds her there, she kept beckoned me
With tiny hand more splendid than a star:
Beckoned and smiledBeckoning and smiling, -- not as mere mortals use,
With risible throes, local and weak at most, --
But with her while bright influence all at once
In gracious act; as smiles the Morning, when
Its subtle lips in rosy glory part
And lengthwise redden, under and above
The pearly clouds; -- and with a voice intense
And intimately tender as the first
Fine feeling of a love-born bliss, and oh!
More silvery in its sweetness to the ear's
Internal test, than seemeth to the eye
The wild white radiance of the maiden Moon,
When from some cape's dark beak her rising mass
OverO'erlooks the ocean, -- even with such a voice,
So keen, so silvery, she kept asking aye
"Where hast thou stayed so long?"
I heard -- but felt
Pass from me forth a cry of instant fear,
As swooning through intensity of joy,
Methought I drifted -- whither? All was now
One wide cold blank -- the Lady and the Tower,
The gleaming Lake, andwith all around it -- one
Wide dreary blank, the drearier for that still
A dizzy, clinging, ghostly consciousness
Kept glimming from mine inmost pulse of life,
Like a far meteor in some dismal marsh:
How long I dreamt not -- but the thrilling warmth
Which, like the new birth of a passionate bliss,
Erewhile had searched me to the quick, again
Shuddered within me, -- more and more, until
Mine eyes had opened under two that made
All else like darkness; and upon my check
A breath that seemed the final spirit of health
And Floral sweetness, harbingered more near
The fond enquiry of that silver voice
Which once to have heard was never to forget:
"Where hast thou stayed so long?"
And when she thus
Had spoken, there came warbled, as it seemed
In mystical respondence to her voice,
Still music, such as Eolus gives forth,
But purer, deeper; -- warbled as from some
Unsearchable recess of soul supreme --
Some depth of the Eternal! echoing thence
Through the sweet meaning of its spirit-speech,
The fond enquiry that awoke me now:
"Where hast thou stayed so long?"
I answered not,
But followed in mute love her eyes with mine,
As in that balcony which up the Tower
Emporched the brazen door, methought I now
Close at her side reclined upon a couch
Of purple, blazoned all with stars of gold
Tremblingly rayed with speculated gems,
And argent moons, -- and bearing cushions, rough
With sheaves of flowers in glowing tissue wrought.
Thus sat we, looking forth: nor did I marvel
As hers now led my vision, to remark
That the broad Lake, with its green shelving shores
Swarming with flowers, andor draped with vines, and thence
The prospect all -- hills, skies, and winding vales,
And bloomy forests of unspeakable beauty,
Were basking in the radianceblessedness of a day
blessedly serene , than everthat never yet

l.add: The perfect of life-essential light

lg.l: Might so enrobe the common world of man
Since Paradise was lost.
I saw all this
Surpassing beauty -- but I saw it thus
Through her superior life, her moon-like sphere
Of being, that seemed the inexhaustible source
(Transpicuously evinced) of breathing thoughts --
Breathing abroad like fragranceodors from a flower;
And effluent idealities; and more
Of rosy passion and affectionate joy,
And earnest tenderness, than many souls
Of Earth's most fervent and ecstatic daughters
United might possess; -- all interflowing
Through the fine issues of a love at once
Wilful and nice, -- but sanctioned none the less
By its so brilliant purity. Nor might
The glassy Lake below more quickly give
Nimble impressions of the coming wind's
Invisible footsteps, dimpling swift along,
Than instant tokens of communion sweet
With outward beauty's subtle spirit, passed
Forth from her eyes, and thence in lambent waves
Suffused and lightened o'er the splendid whole
Of her bright visage, or about her head
In spheres ran raying like a glory of bliss!
But as upon the wonder of her beauty
My soul now feasted, even till it seemed
Instinct with kindred lustre, -- lo, her eyes
Suddenly saddened, and abstractedly
Outfixing them as on some far wild thought
That darkened up over our peacelike a portentous cloudOver the morning of our peace she flung
Her silver voice into a mystic song
Of many measures, gathering as they went,
And sliding on -- a sweet abundant flood
Of metric melody! With which, as still
She poured it forth, invisible Singers mixed
A choral burthen that prolonged the strain's
Rich concords, till the echoes of the hills
Came forth in turn, and, flowing off , afar,
Blent all into one mystery of sound --
One manifold cadence -- dying down. The Song
(Which strangely seemed through all its mystic drift
Addressed to the so stubborn fact , that I
Was sleeping, and its utterer but a Dream!)
Is traced upon the of my soul
In shining lines that intonate themselves --
Not sounding to the ear, but to the thought
Out of the vague vast of the Wonderful!
And might, when hardened into normal speech,
And narrowed from its wide and various sweep
Into such flows as make our waking rhymes
Most wildly musical, be written thus:
Wide apart -- wide apart
In old Time's dim heart,
One terrible Fiend doth his grim watch keep
Over the mystery
Lovely and deep,
Locked up in thy history
Beautiful Sleep!
Could we disarm him --
Could we but charm him,
The soul of the sleeper might happily leap
Through the darkness so dreadful -- so deathly and deep,
That shroudeth the triple divinity
Composing thy mystical Trinity:
Liberty, gratitude,
Boundless beatitude:
Beautiful Spirit of Sleep!
Beautiful Spirit of Sleep!
Could we confound him
Who darkens thy throne,
Could we surround him
With spells like thy own;
For the divinity
Then of thy Trinity
Oh, what a bleeseder reign were begun!
For then were it human, and one
With all that soul, freed from the body's strait scheme,
Inherits of surlight and mystical dream.
And to sleep were to die
Into life in the Infinite,
Holy and high,
Spotless and bright,
And so peacefully deep,
And thence unto liberty, thence unto gratitude,

Beautiful Spirit of Sleep!

This Love itself -- this purpled-winged Love --
This spirit-sweeting Spirit of delight,
Is but a honey-bee of Paradise,
That only in its morning glory dares

And murkiest in the midst -- yea, murkiest there,
Where, big with fate, and hid in solid cloud,
The yet still spirit of the thunder broods,
And menaces the world.
The Lady of Light
Had rushed to my extended arms and hid
Her beamy face, fright-harrowed, in my bosom!
And thus we stood, made one in fear; while still
That terrible Vision notin upon us glared
With horny eyes -- the horrider for that
No touch of passion vitalised their fixed
Eumenidian stone-cold stare, as tow'rds
Some surely destined task they seemed to guide
Its pitiless strength along.
With one dark stride
Then glooming forward, and extending straight
One shadowy arm, from my reluctant grasp
It tore the Radiant Lady, muttering: This
Is love forbidden! in a voice whose tones
Were like low thunders ominously heard
Outroaming from the clouded gorges wild
Of neighboring mountaisn, when a summersultry storm
Is brooding in its dark pavilions there,
And concentrating, like a mighty host,
Ere it rushburst vale-ward; and, as suddenly,
Siezed by the other, I was backward thrown
Within the Tower, and heard ere I could rise
From the cold platform, the huge brazen door
Drawn hoarsly greating to; its beam-like bar
Dropt, with a wall-quake, and itsthe bolts all shot
Into their sockets with a thunderousshattery jar!
I may not paint the horrible despair
That pose me now: (more horrible than aught
In actual destiny, whether bonds or death,
Could give the self-possession of my soul,
If wide awake.) I listened. All was still!
Within -- without -- all silent, stirless, cold.
What was my doom? And where was she, my late
So luminous delight? Gone! Reft away
So strangely -- terribly! and I myself,
For some all unimaginable cause,
A dungeoned wretch! Time, every deep of which
Was as an age, kept trickling on, but there
Brought no release -- no hope -- not even a breath
That spake of fellowship, or even of life,
Out of myself -- my lonely self! I stood
In marble-cold astonishment of heart,
Utterly blank. And when at length I cast
A desperate look -- so desperate, that the power
Of vision stung me like a deadly curse --
Up and around, pure pity of myself
So warmed and loosened from my brain the pent
And icy anguish, that its load at once
Came, like an alp-thaw, streaming through mine eyes;
Till resignation, that so balm sweet
Meck flower of grief thatwhich hath its root in tears
Grew out of mine, and therewith, strength of will
To inspect my Prison.
'Twas a lofty Cell,
Half round, and had within the granite wall
That cut the circle of its floor in twain,
A second door -- shut, and all clamped with
And rough with rows of monstrous iron studs,
And which migh haply have thence opened in
Athward some stairway (as I guessed) that led
Down through the Tower; and by the side of this
A winged Steed upon four dragon claws --
A strange, mute, mystic, almost terrible Thing,
Stood rigid, with a tripod near it placed.
Bare were the dull and rugged walls, but pierced
High out of reach by two small ports that looked
Eastward and westward. -- As I noted these
Full on my sight a transcient sunbeam fell
Slantingly through, and glowed on the damp floor,
A moment, like a streak of burning blood,
Then vanished; wherefore in my heart I guessed
That o'er the mountain tops the sun was then
Ocean-ward sinking.
By degrees the night
Came on , and the Cell darkened: yea, I saw
The Steed and tripod -- all its furniture,
Fade, melting gradually, more and more,
Into the darkness; even as a fish
Through the dense medium of its element
Retiring down, is in its outlines seen
More shadowy -- till 'tis lost. Then all was black.
And two to and fro I paced, hour after hour,
And heard my step, the only sound to me
In th' whole wide world, reverb with a dull blow
Down through the hollow Tower that seemed to yawn
Immeasurably beneath me, -- as it were

A monstrous well, whose wide waste mouth was
bridged
By that dull--quaking strip of floor alone
On which I darkling strode; -- yet on I kept
Pacing, though horrified. Hour after hour
Passed , as if clotting at the heart of Time --
Each an eternity of expectation,
And weary , astonishment -- hour after hour!
And yet no living sound was living there,
Though, as I knew, one live unmoving Thing
So near me stood in that bling solitude --
Stood waiting -- wherefore? by the inner door.
At last, all suddenly, in the air aloft,
O'er the Tower-roof, a wild, weird, wailful song
Woke flying, many-voiced, -- then sweeping off,
Out tow'rds the echoey hills, so passed away
In dying murmurs through the hollow dark.
In vain were our spells wrought,
In vain was she well taught
How that dread Watcher's eyes drowsy to keep;
In vain was the dragon-steed
There at the hour of need
Out with his double fright Blissward to leap.
Lost-lost-lost-lost!
In vain were our spells all of infinite cost!
Lost-lost-lost-lost!
Yon Gulf by a mortal may never be crost!
Never -- ah, never!
The doom holds for ever!
And to aid Her aught more
Is out of our sphere, and transcendeth our lore.
Lost-lost-lost-lost!
Come away -- come away.
Since only in soul yon vague Gulph Gulf may be crost,
See how uprolls the day!
Away to the mystic mid-regions of Sleep.
Lost-lost-lost-lost --
So passed that song: (of which the drift alone
Is here reached after in such leaden speech
As uncharmed mortals use:) and when its tones
Out tow'rds the mountains in the dark afar
Had wasted, I grew sensible, methought,
Of seasonable change; -- that now the Cell
Kept clarifying, till the darkness seemed
Marbled with grey; and then the Steed again,
And tripod, figured indistinctly through
The thinning gloom, and gradually thence
Came forth in full development, by the same
Degrees reversed in which they'd faded there
Into the darkness as the night came on.
It was the Dawn: and thus it charing kept,
Till through the eastern port a golden rod
Of light fell transciently, and so bespake
The sunrise. Oh! it was a dessolate pass,
To feel, -- immured in that so deadly placerelentless Tower keep, --
That then the sun wasHow on the purple hills the sun was then
Rejoicing in his glory. Then to know
My Prison roof: -- hour after hour, to think
That he was tracking with a strip of fire
His midway circle, and thence glorying down
Into the west. But this was my dread fate
while seven times day and night so came; and yet
I slept not! nor (to my amazement) there,
Through all this weary woe, drear time, did the wintry pinchtooth
Of hunger shrunkknaw within my corporal life!
OfNo thirst inflamed me! While ever by thethat grim door
That seemed to shut athwart the stairway, stood
ThatWhich strange, unmoving, dragon-footed steed,
As from the first, and there the tripod, placed
As 'twere to aid some fugitive to mount
At once -- and fly! Mere wonder at my doom,
So unimaginably wild and vague,
Relieved despair.
But on the seventh night -- hark!
What might I hear? -- a step? -- a light small step

Its solid breadth, in subtle wave on wave

With rosy lights that in the darkness fumed
Like luminous odors; at the scent of which
The mystic Steed, so rigid until now,
Moved, and spread wide his glimmering wings. When, hark!
Another step? Yea, the same strenuous tramp
That once before I'd heard big-beating up,
Came following -- till a low sad cry without
Went to my heart, and I might hear ensue
A struggle as of one forced down the stair
By that so ruthless Guard! -- down, till the Cell
Again had darkened, and the Tower itself
Stood once more as in some mute void of Time,
Or depth of distance infinitely out,
Achingly still. But not for long! again
The Monster's hateful tread came booming up,
Quake above quake that with a shudder stopt
Dead at the door! It opened; and he stood
Full in the dubious space: -- but ere the Fiend
Might enter farther, rage and hate at once
Possessed me, and I charged him! For awhile
His horrible glooms voluminously vague,
Yet with a smothering pressure in their folds,
Involved me, -- concentrating more and more,
And lapping closer in yet denser coils,
Each moment! -- but my loathing now had grown
Into so vast a horror, that, methought,
I burst with irresistible strength away!
Rushed through the door, and down the stairway, -- down
An endless depth; till a , hinged
In the Tower's basement, opened to my flight!
No sooner had I passed it than it fell
In thunder to! and thence my passage lay
Along the difficult ledges of a rock
Bordering the Lake. --
And when at last I paused
In that so giddy flight, methought I saw
The lustrous Lady up through the lit air
Ascending, with a steadfast downward look
Of parting recognition, -- full of love,
But painless, passionless. Uh
